Why, when the Charming Sally went down in the\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIn the Baltic Sea, in the dead of night; five-and-twenty minutes past\r\ntwelve when the captain\xe2\x80\x99s watch stopped in his pocket; he lying dead\r\nagainst the main-mast\xe2\x80\x94on the fourteenth of February, seventeen\r\nforty-nine!\xe2\x80\x9d cried Walter, with great animation.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAy, to be sure!\xe2\x80\x9d cried old Sol, \xe2\x80\x9cquite right! Then, there were five\r\nhundred casks of such wine aboard; and all hands (except the first\r\nmate, first lieutenant, two seamen, and a lady, in a leaky boat) going\r\nto work to stave the casks, got drunk and died drunk, singing \xe2\x80\x98Rule\r\nBritannia\xe2\x80\x99, when she settled and went down, and ending with one awful\r\nscream in chorus.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut when the George the Second drove ashore, Uncle, on the coast of\r\nCornwall, in a dismal gale, two hours before daybreak, on the fourth of\r\nMarch, \xe2\x80\x9cseventy-one, she had near two hundred horses aboard; and the\r\nhorses breaking loose down below, early in the gale, and tearing to and\r\nfro, and trampling each other to death, made such noises, and set up\r\nsuch human cries, that the crew believing the ship to be full of\r\ndevils, some of the best men, losing heart and head, went overboard in\r\ndespair, and only two were left alive, at last, to tell the tale.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd when,\xe2\x80\x9d said old Sol, \xe2\x80\x9cwhen the Polyphemus\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPrivate West India Trader, burden three hundred and fifty tons,\r\nCaptain, John Brown of Deptford. Owners, Wiggs and Co.,\xe2\x80\x9d cried Walter.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe same,\xe2\x80\x9d said Sol; \xe2\x80\x9cwhen she took fire, four days\xe2\x80\x99 sail with a fair\r\nwind out of Jamaica Harbour, in the night\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThere were two brothers on board,\xe2\x80\x9d interposed his nephew, speaking\r\nvery fast and loud, \xe2\x80\x9cand there not being room for both of them in the\r\nonly boat that wasn\xe2\x80\x99t swamped, neither of them would consent to go,\r\nuntil the elder took the younger by the waist, and flung him in. And\r\nthen the younger, rising in the boat, cried out, \xe2\x80\x98Dear Edward, think of\r\nyour promised wife at home. I\xe2\x80\x99m only a boy. No one waits at home for\r\nme. Leap down into my place!\xe2\x80\x99 and flung himself in the sea!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe kindling eye and heightened colour of the boy, who had risen from\r\nhis seat in the earnestness of what he said and felt, seemed to remind\r\nold Sol of something he had forgotten, or that his encircling mist had\r\nhitherto shut out. Instead of proceeding with any more anecdotes, as he\r\nhad evidently intended but a moment before, he gave a short dry cough,\r\nand said, \xe2\x80\x9cWell! suppose we change the subject.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe truth was, that the simple-minded Uncle in his secret attraction\r\ntowards the marvellous and adventurous\xe2\x80\x94of which he was, in some sort, a\r\ndistant relation, by his trade\xe2\x80\x94had greatly encouraged the same\r\nattraction in the nephew; and that everything that had ever been put\r\nbefore the boy to deter him from a life of adventure, had had the usual\r\nunaccountable effect of sharpening his taste for it. This is\r\ninvariable. It would seem as if there never was a book written, or a\r\nstory told, expressly with the object of keeping boys on shore, which\r\ndid not lure and charm them to the ocean, as a matter of course.\r\n\r\nBut an addition to the little party now made its appearance, in the\r\nshape of a gentleman in a wide suit of blue, with a hook instead of a\r\nhand attached to his right wrist; very bushy black eyebrows; and a\r\nthick stick in his left hand, covered all over (like his nose) with\r\nknobs. He wore a loose black silk handkerchief round his neck, and such\r\na very large coarse shirt collar, that it looked like a small sail. He\r\nwas evidently the person for whom the spare wine-glass was intended,\r\nand evidently knew it; for having taken off his rough outer coat, and\r\nhung up, on a particular peg behind the door, such a hard glazed hat as\r\na sympathetic person\xe2\x80\x99s head might ache at the sight of, and which left\r\na red rim round his own forehead as if he had been wearing a tight\r\nbasin, he brought a chair to where the clean glass was, and sat himself\r\ndown behind it. He was usually addressed as Captain, this visitor; and\r\nhad been a pilot, or a skipper, or a privateersman, or all three\r\nperhaps; and was a very salt-looking man indeed.\r\n\r\nHis face, remarkable for a brown solidity, brightened as he shook hands\r\nwith Uncle and nephew; but he seemed to be of a laconic disposition,\r\nand merely said:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow goes it?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAll well,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mr Gills, pushing the bottle towards him.\r\n\r\nHe took it up, and having surveyed and smelt it, said with\r\nextraordinary expression:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe,\xe2\x80\x9d returned the Instrument-maker.\r\n\r\nUpon that he whistled as he filled his glass, and seemed to think they\r\nwere making holiday indeed.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWal\xe2\x80\x9dr!\xe2\x80\x9d he said, arranging his hair (which was thin) with his hook,\r\nand then pointing it at the Instrument-maker, \xe2\x80\x9cLook at him! Love!\r\nHonour! And Obey! Overhaul your catechism till you find that passage,\r\nand when found turn the leaf down. Success, my boy!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe was so perfectly satisfied both with his quotation and his reference\r\nto it, that he could not help repeating the words again in a low voice,\r\nand saying he had forgotten \xe2\x80\x99em these forty year.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut I never wanted two or three words in my life that I didn\xe2\x80\x99t know\r\nwhere to lay my hand upon \xe2\x80\x99em, Gills,\xe2\x80\x9d he observed. \xe2\x80\x9cIt comes of not\r\nwasting language as some do.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe reflection perhaps reminded him that he had better, like young\r\nNorval\xe2\x80\x99s father, \xe2\x80\x98increase his store.\xe2\x80\x99 At any rate he became silent,\r\nand remained so, until old Sol went out into the shop to light it up,\r\nwhen he turned to Walter, and said, without any introductory remark:\xe2\x80\x94\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI suppose he could make a clock if he tried?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI shouldn\xe2\x80\x99t wonder, Captain Cuttle,\xe2\x80\x9d returned the boy.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd it would go!\xe2\x80\x9d said Captain Cuttle, making a species of serpent in\r\nthe air with his hook. \xe2\x80\x9cLord, how that clock would go!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nFor a moment or two he seemed quite lost in contemplating the pace of\r\nthis ideal timepiece, and sat looking at the boy as if his face were\r\nthe dial.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut he\xe2\x80\x99s chock-full of science,\xe2\x80\x9d he observed, waving his hook towards\r\nthe stock-in-trade. \xe2\x80\x9cLook\xe2\x80\x99ye here! Here\xe2\x80\x99s a collection of \xe2\x80\x99em. Earth,\r\nair, or water. It\xe2\x80\x99s all one. Only say where you\xe2\x80\x99ll have it. Up in a\r\nballoon? There you are. Down in a bell? There you are. D\xe2\x80\x99ye want to put\r\nthe North Star in a pair of scales and weigh it? He\xe2\x80\x99ll do it for you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nIt may be gathered from these remarks that Captain Cuttle\xe2\x80\x99s reverence\r\nfor the stock of instruments was profound, and that his philosophy knew\r\nlittle or no distinction between trading in it and inventing it.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh!\xe2\x80\x9d he said, with a sigh, \xe2\x80\x9cit\xe2\x80\x99s a fine thing to understand \xe2\x80\x99em. And\r\nyet it\xe2\x80\x99s a fine thing not to understand \xe2\x80\x99em. I hardly know which is\r\nbest. It\xe2\x80\x99s so comfortable to sit here and feel that you might be\r\nweighed, measured, magnified, electrified, polarized, played the very\r\ndevil with: and never know how.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nNothing short of the wonderful Madeira, combined with the occasion\r\n(which rendered it desirable to improve and expand Walter\xe2\x80\x99s mind),\r\ncould have ever loosened his tongue to the extent of giving utterance\r\nto this prodigious oration. He seemed quite amazed himself at the\r\nmanner in which it opened up to view the sources of the taciturn\r\ndelight he had had in eating Sunday dinners in that parlour for ten\r\nyears. Becoming a sadder and a wiser man, he mused and held his peace.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCome!\xe2\x80\x9d cried the subject of this admiration, returning. \xe2\x80\x9cBefore you\r\nhave your glass of grog, Ned, we must finish the bottle.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cStand by!\xe2\x80\x9d said Ned, filling his glass. \xe2\x80\x9cGive the boy some more.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo more, thank\xe2\x80\x99e, Uncle!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, yes,\xe2\x80\x9d said Sol, \xe2\x80\x9ca little more. We\xe2\x80\x99ll finish the bottle, to the\r\nHouse, Ned\xe2\x80\x94Walter\xe2\x80\x99s House. Why it may be his House one of these days,\r\nin part. Who knows? Sir Richard Whittington married his master\xe2\x80\x99s\r\ndaughter.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x98Turn again Whittington, Lord Mayor of London, and when you are old\r\nyou will never depart from it,\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9d interposed the Captain. \xe2\x80\x9cWal\xe2\x80\x9dr!\r\nOverhaul the book, my lad.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd although Mr Dombey hasn\xe2\x80\x99t a daughter,\xe2\x80\x9d Sol began.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, yes, he has, Uncle,\xe2\x80\x9d said the boy, reddening and laughing.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHas he?\xe2\x80\x9d cried the old man. \xe2\x80\x9cIndeed I think he has too.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh! I know he has,\xe2\x80\x9d said the boy. \xe2\x80\x9cSome of \xe2\x80\x99em were talking about it\r\nin the office today. And they do say, Uncle and Captain Cuttle,\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nlowering his voice, \xe2\x80\x9cthat he\xe2\x80\x99s taken a dislike to her, and that she\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nleft, unnoticed, among the servants, and that his mind\xe2\x80\x99s so set all the\r\nwhile upon having his son in the House, that although he\xe2\x80\x99s only a baby\r\nnow, he is going to have balances struck oftener than formerly, and the\r\nbooks kept closer than they used to be, and has even been seen (when he\r\nthought he wasn\xe2\x80\x99t) walking in the Docks, looking at his ships and\r\nproperty and all that, as if he was exulting like, over what he and his\r\nson will possess together. That\xe2\x80\x99s what they say. Of course, I don\xe2\x80\x99t\r\nknow.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe knows all about her already, you see,\xe2\x80\x9d said the instrument-maker.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNonsense, Uncle,\xe2\x80\x9d cried the boy, still reddening and laughing,\r\nboy-like. \xe2\x80\x9cHow can I help hearing what they tell me?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe son\xe2\x80\x99s a little in our way at present, I\xe2\x80\x99m afraid, Ned,\xe2\x80\x9d said the\r\nold man, humouring the joke.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cVery much,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Captain.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNevertheless, we\xe2\x80\x99ll drink him,\xe2\x80\x9d pursued Sol. \xe2\x80\x9cSo, here\xe2\x80\x99s to Dombey and\r\nSon.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, very well, Uncle,\xe2\x80\x9d said the boy, merrily. \xe2\x80\x9cSince you have\r\nintroduced the mention of her, and have connected me with her and have\r\nsaid that I know all about her, I shall make bold to amend the toast.\r\nSo here\xe2\x80\x99s to Dombey\xe2\x80\x94and Son\xe2\x80\x94and Daughter!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER V.\r\nPaul\xe2\x80\x99s Progress and Christening\r\n\r\n\r\nLittle Paul, suffering no contamination from the blood of the Toodles,\r\ngrew stouter and stronger every day. Every day, too, he was more and\r\nmore ardently cherished by Miss Tox, whose devotion was so far\r\nappreciated by Mr Dombey that he began to regard her as a woman of\r\ngreat natural good sense, whose feelings did her credit and deserved\r\nencouragement. He was so lavish of this condescension, that he not only\r\nbowed to her, in a particular manner, on several occasions, but even\r\nentrusted such stately recognitions of her to his sister as \xe2\x80\x9cpray tell\r\nyour friend, Louisa, that she is very good,\xe2\x80\x9d or \xe2\x80\x9cmention to Miss Tox,\r\nLouisa, that I am obliged to her;\xe2\x80\x9d specialities which made a deep\r\nimpression on the lady thus distinguished.\r\n\r\nWhether Miss Tox conceived that having been selected by the Fates to\r\nwelcome the little Dombey before he was born, in Kirby, Beard and\r\nKirby\xe2\x80\x99s Best Mixed Pins, it therefore naturally devolved upon her to\r\ngreet him with all other forms of welcome in all other early stages of\r\nhis existence\xe2\x80\x94or whether her overflowing goodness induced her to\r\nvolunteer into the domestic militia as a substitute in some sort for\r\nhis deceased Mama\xe2\x80\x94or whether she was conscious of any other motives\xe2\x80\x94are\r\nquestions which in this stage of the Firm\xe2\x80\x99s history herself only could\r\nhave solved. Nor have they much bearing on the fact (of which there is\r\nno doubt), that Miss Tox\xe2\x80\x99s constancy and zeal were a heavy\r\ndiscouragement to Richards, who lost flesh hourly under her patronage,\r\nand was in some danger of being superintended to death.\r\n\r\nMiss Tox was often in the habit of assuring Mrs Chick, that nothing\r\ncould exceed her interest in all connected with the development of that\r\nsweet child; and an observer of Miss Tox\xe2\x80\x99s proceedings might have\r\ninferred so much without declaratory confirmation. She would preside\r\nover the innocent repasts of the young heir, with ineffable\r\nsatisfaction, almost with an air of joint proprietorship with Richards\r\nin the entertainment. At the little ceremonies of the bath and\r\ntoilette, she assisted with enthusiasm. The administration of infantine\r\ndoses of physic awakened all the active sympathy of her character; and\r\nbeing on one occasion secreted in a cupboard (whither she had fled in\r\nmodesty), when Mr Dombey was introduced into the nursery by his sister,\r\nto behold his son, in the course of preparation for bed, taking a short\r\nwalk uphill over Richards\xe2\x80\x99s gown, in a short and airy linen jacket,\r\nMiss Tox was so transported beyond the ignorant present as to be unable\r\nto refrain from crying out, \xe2\x80\x9cIs he not beautiful Mr Dombey! Is he not a\r\nCupid, Sir!\xe2\x80\x9d and then almost sinking behind the closet door with\r\nconfusion and blushes.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLouisa,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mr Dombey, one day, to his sister, \xe2\x80\x9cI really think I\r\nmust present your friend with some little token, on the occasion of\r\nPaul\xe2\x80\x99s christening. She has exerted herself so warmly in the child\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nbehalf from the first, and seems to understand her position so\r\nthoroughly (a very rare merit in this world, I am sorry to say), that\r\nit would really be agreeable to me to notice her.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nLet it be no detraction from the merits of Miss Tox, to hint that in Mr\r\nDombey\xe2\x80\x99s eyes, as in some others that occasionally see the light, they\r\nonly achieved that mighty piece of knowledge, the understanding of\r\ntheir own position, who showed a fitting reverence for his. It was not\r\nso much their merit that they knew themselves, as that they knew him,\r\nand bowed low before him.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy dear Paul,\xe2\x80\x9d returned his sister, \xe2\x80\x9cyou do Miss Tox but justice, as a\r\nman of your penetration was sure, I knew, to do. I believe if there are\r\nthree words in the English language for which she has a respect\r\namounting almost to veneration, those words are, Dombey and Son.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mr Dombey, \xe2\x80\x9cI believe it. It does Miss Tox credit.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd as to anything in the shape of a token, my dear Paul,\xe2\x80\x9d pursued his\r\nsister, \xe2\x80\x9call I can say is that anything you give Miss Tox will be\r\nhoarded and prized, I am sure, like a relic. But there is a way, my\r\ndear Paul, of showing your sense of Miss Tox\xe2\x80\x99s friendliness in a still\r\nmore flattering and acceptable manner, if you should be so inclined.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow is that?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Mr Dombey.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGodfathers, of course,\xe2\x80\x9d continued Mrs Chick, \xe2\x80\x9care important in point\r\nof connexion and influence.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI don\xe2\x80\x99t know why they should be, to my son,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mr Dombey, coldly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cVery true, my dear Paul,\xe2\x80\x9d retorted Mrs Chick, with an extraordinary\r\nshow of animation, to cover the suddenness of her conversion; \xe2\x80\x9cand\r\nspoken like yourself. I might have expected nothing else from you. I\r\nmight have known that such would have been your opinion. Perhaps;\xe2\x80\x9d here\r\nMrs Chick faltered again, as not quite comfortably feeling her way;\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cperhaps that is a reason why you might have the less objection to\r\nallowing Miss Tox to be godmother to the dear thing, if it were only as\r\ndeputy and proxy for someone else. That it would be received as a great\r\nhonour and distinction, Paul, I need not say.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLouisa,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mr Dombey, after a short pause, \xe2\x80\x9cit is not to be\r\nsupposed\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCertainly not,\xe2\x80\x9d cried Mrs Chick, hastening to anticipate a refusal, \xe2\x80\x9cI\r\nnever thought it was.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMr Dombey looked at her impatiently.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDon\xe2\x80\x99t flurry me, my dear Paul,\xe2\x80\x9d said his sister; \xe2\x80\x9cfor that destroys\r\nme. I am far from strong. I have not been quite myself, since poor dear\r\nFanny departed.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMr Dombey glanced at the pocket-handkerchief which his sister applied\r\nto her eyes, and resumed:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is not be supposed, I say\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd I say,\xe2\x80\x9d murmured Mrs Chick, \xe2\x80\x9cthat I never thought it was.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGood Heaven, Louisa!\xe2\x80\x9d said Mr Dombey.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, my dear Paul,\xe2\x80\x9d she remonstrated with tearful dignity, \xe2\x80\x9cI must\r\nreally be allowed to speak. I am not so clever, or so reasoning, or so\r\neloquent, or so anything, as you are. I know that very well. So much\r\nthe worse for me. But if they were the last words I had to utter\xe2\x80\x94and\r\nlast words should be very solemn to you and me, Paul, after poor dear\r\nFanny\xe2\x80\x94I would still say I never thought it was. And what is more,\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nadded Mrs Chick with increased dignity, as if she had withheld her\r\ncrushing argument until now, \xe2\x80\x9cI never did think it was.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMr Dombey walked to the window and back again.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is not to be supposed, Louisa,\xe2\x80\x9d he said (Mrs Chick had nailed her\r\ncolours to the mast, and repeated \xe2\x80\x9cI know it isn\xe2\x80\x99t,\xe2\x80\x9d but he took no\r\nnotice of it), \xe2\x80\x9cbut that there are many persons who, supposing that I\r\nrecognised any claim at all in such a case, have a claim upon me\r\nsuperior to Miss Tox\xe2\x80\x99s. But I do not. I recognise no such thing. Paul\r\nand myself will be able, when the time comes, to hold our own\xe2\x80\x94the\r\nHouse, in other words, will be able to hold its own, and maintain its\r\nown, and hand down its own of itself, and without any such common-place\r\naids. The kind of foreign help which people usually seek for their\r\nchildren, I can afford to despise; being above it, I hope. So that\r\nPaul\xe2\x80\x99s infancy and childhood pass away well, and I see him becoming\r\nqualified without waste of time for the career on which he is destined\r\nto enter, I am satisfied. He will make what powerful friends he pleases\r\nin after-life, when he is actively maintaining\xe2\x80\x94and extending, if that\r\nis possible\xe2\x80\x94the dignity and credit of the Firm. Until then, I am enough\r\nfor him, perhaps, and all in all. I have no wish that people should\r\nstep in between us. I would much rather show my sense of the obliging\r\nconduct of a deserving person like your friend. Therefore let it be so;\r\nand your husband and myself will do well enough for the other sponsors,\r\nI daresay.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nIn the course of these remarks, delivered with great majesty and\r\ngrandeur, Mr Dombey had truly revealed the secret feelings of his\r\nbreast. An indescribable distrust of anybody stepping in between\r\nhimself and his son; a haughty dread of having any rival or partner in\r\nthe boy\xe2\x80\x99s respect and deference; a sharp misgiving, recently acquired,\r\nthat he was not infallible in his power of bending and binding human\r\nwills; as sharp a jealousy of any second check or cross; these were, at\r\nthat time the master keys of his soul. In all his life, he had never\r\nmade a friend. His cold and distant nature had neither sought one, nor\r\nfound one. And now, when that nature concentrated its whole force so\r\nstrongly on a partial scheme of parental interest and ambition, it\r\nseemed as if its icy current, instead of being released by this\r\ninfluence, and running clear and free, had thawed for but an instant to\r\nadmit its burden, and then frozen with it into one unyielding block.\r\n\r\nElevated thus to the godmothership of little Paul, in virtue of her\r\ninsignificance, Miss Tox was from that hour chosen and appointed to\r\noffice; and Mr Dombey further signified his pleasure that the ceremony,\r\nalready long delayed, should take place without further postponement.\r\nHis sister, who had been far from anticipating so signal a success,\r\nwithdrew as soon as she could, to communicate it to her best of\r\nfriends; and Mr Dombey was left alone in his library. He had already\r\nlaid his hand upon the bellrope to convey his usual summons to\r\nRichards, when his eye fell upon a writing-desk, belonging to his\r\ndeceased wife, which had been taken, among other things, from a cabinet\r\nin her chamber. It was not the first time that his eye had lighted on\r\nit He carried the key in his pocket; and he brought it to his table and\r\nopened it now\xe2\x80\x94having previously locked the room door\xe2\x80\x94with a\r\nwell-accustomed hand.\r\n\r\nFrom beneath a leaf of torn and cancelled scraps of paper, he took one\r\nletter that remained entire. Involuntarily holding his breath as he\r\nopened this document, and \xe2\x80\x9cbating in the stealthy action something of\r\nhis arrogant demeanour, he sat down, resting his head upon one hand,\r\nand read it through.\r\n\r\nHe read it slowly and attentively, and with a nice particularity to\r\nevery syllable. Otherwise than as his great deliberation seemed\r\nunnatural, and perhaps the result of an effort equally great, he\r\nallowed no sign of emotion to escape him. When he had read it through,\r\nhe folded and refolded it slowly several times, and tore it carefully\r\ninto fragments. Checking his hand in the act of throwing these away, he\r\nput them in his pocket, as if unwilling to trust them even to the\r\nchances of being re-united and deciphered; and instead of ringing, as\r\nusual, for little Paul, he sat solitary, all the evening, in his\r\ncheerless room.\r\n\r\nThere was anything but solitude in the nursery; for there, Mrs Chick\r\nand Miss Tox were enjoying a social evening, so much to the disgust of\r\nMiss Susan Nipper, that that young lady embraced every opportunity of\r\nmaking wry faces behind the door. Her feelings were so much excited on\r\nthe occasion, that she found it indispensable to afford them this\r\nrelief, even without having the comfort of any audience or sympathy\r\nwhatever. As the knight-errants of old relieved their minds by carving\r\ntheir mistress\xe2\x80\x99s names in deserts, and wildernesses, and other savage\r\nplaces where there was no probability of there ever being anybody to\r\nread them, so did Miss Susan Nipper curl her snub nose into drawers and\r\nwardrobes, put away winks of disparagement in cupboards, shed derisive\r\nsquints into stone pitchers, and contradict and call names out in the\r\npassage.\r\n\r\nThe two interlopers, however, blissfully unconscious of the young\r\nlady\xe2\x80\x99s sentiments, saw little Paul safe through all the stages of\r\nundressing, airy exercise, supper and bed; and then sat down to tea\r\nbefore the fire. The two children now lay, through the good offices of\r\nPolly, in one room; and it was not until the ladies were established at\r\ntheir tea-table that, happening to look towards the little beds, they\r\nthought of Florence.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow sound she sleeps!\xe2\x80\x9d said Miss Tox.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy, you know, my dear, she takes a great deal of exercise in the\r\ncourse of the day,\xe2\x80\x9d returned Mrs Chick, \xe2\x80\x9cplaying about little Paul so\r\nmuch.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cShe is a curious child,\xe2\x80\x9d said Miss Tox.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy dear,\xe2\x80\x9d retorted Mrs Chick, in a low voice: \xe2\x80\x9cHer Mama, all over!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIn-deed!\xe2\x80\x9d said Miss Tox. \xe2\x80\x9cAh dear me!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nA tone of most extraordinary compassion Miss Tox said it in, though she\r\nhad no distinct idea why, except that it was expected of her.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFlorence will never, never, never be a Dombey,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mrs Chick, \xe2\x80\x9cnot\r\nif she lives to be a thousand years old.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMiss Tox elevated her eyebrows, and was again full of commiseration.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI quite fret and worry myself about her,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mrs Chick, with a sigh\r\nof modest merit. \xe2\x80\x9cI really don\xe2\x80\x99t see what is to become of her when she\r\ngrows older, or what position she is to take. She don\xe2\x80\x99t gain on her\r\nPapa in the least. How can one expect she should, when she is so very\r\nunlike a Dombey?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMiss Tox looked as if she saw no way out of such a cogent argument as\r\nthat, at all.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd the child, you see,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mrs Chick, in deep confidence, \xe2\x80\x9chas poor\r\ndear Fanny\xe2\x80\x99s nature. She\xe2\x80\x99ll never make an effort in after-life, I\xe2\x80\x99ll\r\nventure to say. Never! She\xe2\x80\x99ll never wind and twine herself about her\r\nPapa\xe2\x80\x99s heart like\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLike the ivy?\xe2\x80\x9d suggested Miss Tox.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLike the ivy,\xe2\x80\x9d Mrs Chick assented. \xe2\x80\x9cNever! She\xe2\x80\x99ll never glide and\r\nnestle into the bosom of her Papa\xe2\x80\x99s affections like\xe2\x80\x94the\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cStartled fawn?\xe2\x80\x9d suggested Miss Tox.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLike the startled fawn,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mrs Chick. \xe2\x80\x9cNever! Poor Fanny! Yet, how\r\nI loved her!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou must not distress yourself, my dear,\xe2\x80\x9d said Miss Tox, in a soothing\r\nvoice. \xe2\x80\x9cNow really! You have too much feeling.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWe have all our faults,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mrs Chick, weeping and shaking her head.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI daresay we have. I never was blind to hers. I never said I was. Far\r\nfrom it. Yet how I loved her!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nWhat a satisfaction it was to Mrs Chick\xe2\x80\x94a common-place piece of folly\r\nenough, compared with whom her sister-in-law had been a very angel of\r\nwomanly intelligence and gentleness\xe2\x80\x94to patronise and be tender to the\r\nmemory of that lady: in exact pursuance of her conduct to her in her\r\nlifetime: and to thoroughly believe herself, and take herself in, and\r\nmake herself uncommonly comfortable on the strength of her toleration!\r\nWhat a mighty pleasant virtue toleration should be when we are right,\r\nto be so very pleasant when we are wrong, and quite unable to\r\ndemonstrate how we come to be invested with the privilege of exercising\r\nit!\r\n\r\nMrs Chick was yet drying her eyes and shaking her head, when Richards\r\nmade bold to caution her that Miss Florence was awake and sitting in\r\nher bed. She had risen, as the nurse said, and the lashes of her eyes\r\nwere wet with tears. But no one saw them glistening save Polly. No one\r\nelse leant over her, and whispered soothing words to her, or was near\r\nenough to hear the flutter of her beating heart.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh! dear nurse!\xe2\x80\x9d said the child, looking earnestly up in her face,\r\n\xe2\x80\x9clet me lie by my brother!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy, my pet?\xe2\x80\x9d said Richards.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh! I think he loves me,\xe2\x80\x9d cried the child wildly. \xe2\x80\x9cLet me lie by him.\r\nPray do!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMrs Chick interposed with some motherly words about going to sleep like\r\na dear, but Florence repeated her supplication, with a frightened look,\r\nand in a voice broken by sobs and tears.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ll not wake him,\xe2\x80\x9d she said, covering her face and hanging down her\r\nhead. \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ll only touch him with my hand, and go to sleep. Oh, pray,\r\npray, let me lie by my brother tonight, for I believe he\xe2\x80\x99s fond of\r\nme!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nRichards took her without a word, and carrying her to the little bed in\r\nwhich the infant was sleeping, laid her down by his side. She crept as\r\nnear him as she could without disturbing his rest; and stretching out\r\none arm so that it timidly embraced his neck, and hiding her face on\r\nthe other, over which her damp and scattered hair fell loose, lay\r\nmotionless.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPoor little thing,\xe2\x80\x9d said Miss Tox; \xe2\x80\x9cshe has been dreaming, I daresay.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nDreaming, perhaps, of loving tones for ever silent, of loving eyes for\r\never closed, of loving arms again wound round her, and relaxing in that\r\ndream within the dam which no tongue can relate. Seeking, perhaps\xe2\x80\x94in\r\ndreams\xe2\x80\x94some natural comfort for a heart, deeply and sorely wounded,\r\nthough so young a child\xe2\x80\x99s: and finding it, perhaps, in dreams, if not\r\nin waking, cold, substantial truth. This trivial incident had so\r\ninterrupted the current of conversation, that it was difficult of\r\nresumption; and Mrs Chick moreover had been so affected by the\r\ncontemplation of her own tolerant nature, that she was not in spirits.\r\nThe two friends accordingly soon made an end of their tea, and a\r\nservant was despatched to fetch a hackney cabriolet for Miss Tox. Miss\r\nTox had great experience in hackney cabs, and her starting in one was\r\ngenerally a work of time, as she was systematic in the preparatory\r\narrangements.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHave the goodness, if you please, Towlinson,\xe2\x80\x9d said Miss Tox, \xe2\x80\x9cfirst of\r\nall, to carry out a pen and ink and take his number legibly.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, Miss,\xe2\x80\x9d said Towlinson.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen, if you please, Towlinson,\xe2\x80\x9d said Miss Tox, \xe2\x80\x9chave the goodness to\r\nturn the cushion. Which,\xe2\x80\x9d said Miss Tox apart to Mrs Chick, \xe2\x80\x9cis\r\ngenerally damp, my dear.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, Miss,\xe2\x80\x9d said Towlinson.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ll trouble you also, if you please, Towlinson,\xe2\x80\x9d said Miss Tox, \xe2\x80\x9cwith\r\nthis card and this shilling. He\xe2\x80\x99s to drive to the card, and is to\r\nunderstand that he will not on any account have more than the\r\nshilling.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, Miss,\xe2\x80\x9d said Towlinson.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd\xe2\x80\x94I\xe2\x80\x99m sorry to give you so much trouble, Towlinson,\xe2\x80\x9d said Miss Tox,\r\nlooking at him pensively.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNot at all, Miss,\xe2\x80\x9d said Towlinson.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMention to the man, then, if you please, Towlinson,\xe2\x80\x9d said Miss Tox,\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cthat the lady\xe2\x80\x99s uncle is a magistrate, and that if he gives her any of\r\nhis impertinence he will be punished terribly. You can pretend to say\r\nthat, if you please, Towlinson, in a friendly way, and because you know\r\nit was done to another man, who died.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCertainly, Miss,\xe2\x80\x9d said Towlinson.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd now good-night to my sweet, sweet, sweet, godson,\xe2\x80\x9d said Miss Tox,\r\nwith a soft shower of kisses at each repetition of the adjective; \xe2\x80\x9cand\r\nLouisa, my dear friend, promise me to take a little something warm\r\nbefore you go to bed, and not to distress yourself!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nIt was with extreme difficulty that Nipper, the black-eyed, who looked\r\non steadfastly, contained herself at this crisis, and until the\r\nsubsequent departure of Mrs Chick. But the nursery being at length free\r\nof visitors, she made herself some recompense for her late restraint.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou might keep me in a strait-waistcoat for six weeks,\xe2\x80\x9d said Nipper,\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cand when I got it off I\xe2\x80\x99d only be more aggravated, who ever heard the\r\nlike of them two Griffins, Mrs Richards?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd then to talk of having been dreaming, poor dear!\xe2\x80\x9d said Polly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh you beauties!\xe2\x80\x9d cried Susan Nipper, affecting to salute the door by\r\nwhich the ladies had departed. \xe2\x80\x9cNever be a Dombey won\xe2\x80\x99t she? It\xe2\x80\x99s to be\r\nhoped she won\xe2\x80\x99t, we don\xe2\x80\x99t want any more such, one\xe2\x80\x99s enough.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDon\xe2\x80\x99t wake the children, Susan dear,\xe2\x80\x9d said Polly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m very much beholden to you, Mrs Richards,\xe2\x80\x9d said Susan, who was not\r\nby any means discriminating in her wrath, \xe2\x80\x9cand really feel it as a\r\nhonour to receive your commands, being a black slave and a mulotter.\r\nMrs Richards, if there\xe2\x80\x99s any other orders, you can give me, pray\r\nmention \xe2\x80\x99em.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNonsense; orders,\xe2\x80\x9d said Polly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh! bless your heart, Mrs Richards,\xe2\x80\x9d cried Susan, \xe2\x80\x9ctemporaries always\r\norders permanencies here, didn\xe2\x80\x99t you know that, why wherever was you\r\nborn, Mrs Richards? But wherever you was born, Mrs Richards,\xe2\x80\x9d pursued\r\nSpitfire, shaking her head resolutely, \xe2\x80\x9cand whenever, and however\r\n(which is best known to yourself), you may bear in mind, please, that\r\nit\xe2\x80\x99s one thing to give orders, and quite another thing to take \xe2\x80\x99em. A\r\nperson may tell a person to dive off a bridge head foremost into\r\nfive-and-forty feet of water, Mrs Richards, but a person may be very\r\nfar from diving.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThere now,\xe2\x80\x9d said Polly, \xe2\x80\x9cyou\xe2\x80\x99re angry because you\xe2\x80\x99re a good little\r\nthing, and fond of Miss Florence; and yet you turn round on me, because\r\nthere\xe2\x80\x99s nobody else.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s very easy for some to keep their tempers, and be soft-spoken, Mrs\r\nRichards,\xe2\x80\x9d returned Susan, slightly mollified, \xe2\x80\x9cwhen their child\xe2\x80\x99s made\r\nas much of as a prince, and is petted and patted till it wishes its\r\nfriends further, but when a sweet young pretty innocent, that never\r\nought to have a cross word spoken to or of it, is rundown, the case is\r\nvery different indeed. My goodness gracious me, Miss Floy, you naughty,\r\nsinful child, if you don\xe2\x80\x99t shut your eyes this minute, I\xe2\x80\x99ll call in\r\nthem hobgoblins that lives in the cock-loft to come and eat you up\r\nalive!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHere Miss Nipper made a horrible lowing, supposed to issue from a\r\nconscientious goblin of the bull species, impatient to discharge the\r\nsevere duty of his position. Having further composed her young charge\r\nby covering her head with the bedclothes, and making three or four\r\nangry dabs at the pillow, she folded her arms, and screwed up her\r\nmouth, and sat looking at the fire for the rest of the evening.\r\n\r\nThough little Paul was said, in nursery phrase, \xe2\x80\x9cto take a deal of\r\nnotice for his age,\xe2\x80\x9d he took as little notice of all this as of the\r\npreparations for his christening on the next day but one; which\r\nnevertheless went on about him, as to his personal apparel, and that of\r\nhis sister and the two nurses, with great activity. Neither did he, on\r\nthe arrival of the appointed morning, show any sense of its importance;\r\nbeing, on the contrary, unusually inclined to sleep, and unusually\r\ninclined to take it ill in his attendants that they dressed him to go\r\nout.\r\n\r\nIt happened to be an iron-grey autumnal day, with a shrewd east wind\r\nblowing\xe2\x80\x94a day in keeping with the proceedings. Mr Dombey represented in\r\nhimself the wind, the shade, and the autumn of the christening. He\r\nstood in his library to receive the company, as hard and cold as the\r\nweather; and when he looked out through the glass room, at the trees in\r\nthe little garden, their brown and yellow leaves came fluttering down,\r\nas if he blighted them.\r\n\r\nUgh! They were black, cold rooms; and seemed to be in mourning, like\r\nthe inmates of the house. The books precisely matched as to size, and\r\ndrawn up in line, like soldiers, looked in their cold, hard, slippery\r\nuniforms, as if they had but one idea among them, and that was a\r\nfreezer. The bookcase, glazed and locked, repudiated all familiarities.\r\nMr Pitt, in bronze, on the top, with no trace of his celestial origin\r\nabout him, guarded the unattainable treasure like an enchanted Moor. A\r\ndusty urn at each high corner, dug up from an ancient tomb, preached\r\ndesolation and decay, as from two pulpits; and the chimney-glass,\r\nreflecting Mr Dombey and his portrait at one blow, seemed fraught with\r\nmelancholy meditations.\r\n\r\nThe stiff and stark fire-irons appeared to claim a nearer relationship\r\nthan anything else there to Mr Dombey, with his buttoned coat, his\r\nwhite cravat, his heavy gold watch-chain, and his creaking boots. But\r\nthis was before the arrival of Mr and Mrs Chick, his lawful relatives,\r\nwho soon presented themselves.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy dear Paul,\xe2\x80\x9d Mrs Chick murmured, as she embraced him, \xe2\x80\x9cthe\r\nbeginning, I hope, of many joyful days!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThank you, Louisa,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mr Dombey, grimly. \xe2\x80\x9cHow do you do, Mr John?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow do you do, Sir?\xe2\x80\x9d said Chick.\r\n\r\nHe gave Mr Dombey his hand, as if he feared it might electrify him.
