Withers is\r\nmore a child to me than you are. He attends to me much more than my own\r\ndaughter. I almost wish I didn\xe2\x80\x99t look so young\xe2\x80\x94and all that kind of\r\nthing\xe2\x80\x94and then perhaps I should be more considered.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat would you have, mother?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, a great deal, Edith,\xe2\x80\x9d impatiently.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIs there anything you want that you have not? It is your own fault if\r\nthere be.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy own fault!\xe2\x80\x9d beginning to whimper. \xe2\x80\x9cThe parent I have been to you,\r\nEdith: making you a companion from your cradle! And when you neglect\r\nme, and have no more natural affection for me than if I was a\r\nstranger\xe2\x80\x94not a twentieth part of the affection that you have for\r\nFlorence\xe2\x80\x94but I am only your mother, and should corrupt her in a\r\nday!\xe2\x80\x94you reproach me with its being my own fault.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMother, mother, I reproach you with nothing. Why will you always dwell\r\non this?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIsn\xe2\x80\x99t it natural that I should dwell on this, when I am all affection\r\nand sensitiveness, and am wounded in the cruellest way, whenever you\r\nlook at me?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI do not mean to wound you, mother. Have you no remembrance of what\r\nhas been said between us? Let the Past rest.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, rest! And let gratitude to me rest; and let affection for me\r\nrest; and let me rest in my out-of-the-way room, with no society and no\r\nattention, while you find new relations to make much of, who have no\r\nearthly claim upon you! Good gracious, Edith, do you know what an\r\nelegant establishment you are at the head of?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes. Hush!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd that gentlemanly creature, Dombey? Do you know that you are\r\nmarried to him, Edith, and that you have a settlement and a position,\r\nand a carriage, and I don\xe2\x80\x99t know what?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIndeed, I know it, mother; well.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAs you would have had with that delightful good soul\xe2\x80\x94what did they\r\ncall him?\xe2\x80\x94Granger\xe2\x80\x94if he hadn\xe2\x80\x99t died. And who have you to thank for all\r\nthis, Edith?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou, mother; you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen put your arms round my neck, and kiss me; and show me, Edith,\r\nthat you know there never was a better Mama than I have been to you.\r\nAnd don\xe2\x80\x99t let me become a perfect fright with teasing and wearing\r\nmyself at your ingratitude, or when I\xe2\x80\x99m out again in society no soul\r\nwill know me, not even that hateful animal, the Major.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nBut, sometimes, when Edith went nearer to her, and bending down her\r\nstately head, put her cold cheek to hers, the mother would draw back as\r\nIf she were afraid of her, and would fall into a fit of trembling, and\r\ncry out that there was a wandering in her wits. And sometimes she would\r\nentreat her, with humility, to sit down on the chair beside her bed,\r\nand would look at her (as she sat there brooding) with a face that even\r\nthe rose-coloured curtains could not make otherwise than scared and\r\nwild.\r\n\r\nThe rose-coloured curtains blushed, in course of time, on Cleopatra\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nbodily recovery, and on her dress\xe2\x80\x94more juvenile than ever, to repair\r\nthe ravages of illness\xe2\x80\x94and on the rouge, and on the teeth, and on the\r\ncurls, and on the diamonds, and the short sleeves, and the whole\r\nwardrobe of the doll that had tumbled down before the mirror. They\r\nblushed, too, now and then, upon an indistinctness in her speech which\r\nshe turned off with a girlish giggle, and on an occasional failing in\r\nher memory, that had no rule in it, but came and went fantastically, as\r\nif in mockery of her fantastic self.\r\n\r\nBut they never blushed upon a change in the new manner of her thought\r\nand speech towards her daughter. And though that daughter often came\r\nwithin their influence, they never blushed upon her loveliness\r\nirradiated by a smile, or softened by the light of filial love, in its\r\nstern beauty.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER XXXVIII.\r\nMiss Tox improves an Old Acquaintance\r\n\r\n\r\nThe forlorn Miss Tox, abandoned by her friend Louisa Chick, and bereft\r\nof Mr Dombey\xe2\x80\x99s countenance\xe2\x80\x94for no delicate pair of wedding cards,\r\nunited by a silver thread, graced the chimney-glass in Princess\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nPlace, or the harpsichord, or any of those little posts of display\r\nwhich Lucretia reserved for holiday occupation\xe2\x80\x94became depressed in her\r\nspirits, and suffered much from melancholy. For a time the Bird Waltz\r\nwas unheard in Princess\xe2\x80\x99s Place, the plants were neglected, and dust\r\ncollected on the miniature of Miss Tox\xe2\x80\x99s ancestor with the powdered\r\nhead and pigtail.\r\n\r\nMiss Tox, however, was not of an age or of a disposition long to\r\nabandon herself to unavailing regrets. Only two notes of the\r\nharpsichord were dumb from disuse when the Bird Waltz again warbled and\r\ntrilled in the crooked drawing-room: only one slip of geranium fell a\r\nvictim to imperfect nursing, before she was gardening at her green\r\nbaskets again, regularly every morning; the powdered-headed ancestor\r\nhad not been under a cloud for more than six weeks, when Miss Tox\r\nbreathed on his benignant visage, and polished him up with a piece of\r\nwash-leather.\r\n\r\nStill, Miss Tox was lonely, and at a loss. Her attachments, however\r\nludicrously shown, were real and strong; and she was, as she expressed\r\nit, \xe2\x80\x9cdeeply hurt by the unmerited contumely she had met with from\r\nLouisa.\xe2\x80\x9d But there was no such thing as anger in Miss Tox\xe2\x80\x99s\r\ncomposition. If she had ambled on through life, in her soft spoken way,\r\nwithout any opinions, she had, at least, got so far without any harsh\r\npassions. The mere sight of Louisa Chick in the street one day, at a\r\nconsiderable distance, so overpowered her milky nature, that she was\r\nfain to seek immediate refuge in a pastrycook\xe2\x80\x99s, and there, in a musty\r\nlittle back room usually devoted to the consumption of soups, and\r\npervaded by an ox-tail atmosphere, relieve her feelings by weeping\r\nplentifully.\r\n\r\nAgainst Mr Dombey Miss Tox hardly felt that she had any reason of\r\ncomplaint. Her sense of that gentleman\xe2\x80\x99s magnificence was such, that\r\nonce removed from him, she felt as if her distance always had been\r\nimmeasurable, and as if he had greatly condescended in tolerating her\r\nat all. No wife could be too handsome or too stately for him, according\r\nto Miss Tox\xe2\x80\x99s sincere opinion. It was perfectly natural that in looking\r\nfor one, he should look high. Miss Tox with tears laid down this\r\nproposition, and fully admitted it, twenty times a day. She never\r\nrecalled the lofty manner in which Mr Dombey had made her subservient\r\nto his convenience and caprices, and had graciously permitted her to be\r\none of the nurses of his little son. She only thought, in her own\r\nwords, \xe2\x80\x9cthat she had passed a great many happy hours in that house,\r\nwhich she must ever remember with gratification, and that she could\r\nnever cease to regard Mr Dombey as one of the most impressive and\r\ndignified of men.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nCut off, however, from the implacable Louisa, and being shy of the\r\nMajor (whom she viewed with some distrust now), Miss Tox found it very\r\nirksome to know nothing of what was going on in Mr Dombey\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nestablishment. And as she really had got into the habit of considering\r\nDombey and Son as the pivot on which the world in general turned, she\r\nresolved, rather than be ignorant of intelligence which so strongly\r\ninterested her, to cultivate her old acquaintance, Mrs Richards, who\r\nshe knew, since her last memorable appearance before Mr Dombey, was in\r\nthe habit of sometimes holding communication with his servants. Perhaps\r\nMiss Tox, in seeking out the Toodle family, had the tender motive\r\nhidden in her breast of having somebody to whom she could talk about Mr\r\nDombey, no matter how humble that somebody might be.\r\n\r\nAt all events, towards the Toodle habitation Miss Tox directed her\r\nsteps one evening, what time Mr Toodle, cindery and swart, was\r\nrefreshing himself with tea, in the bosom of his family. Mr Toodle had\r\nonly three stages of existence. He was either taking refreshment in the\r\nbosom just mentioned, or he was tearing through the country at from\r\ntwenty-five to fifty miles an hour, or he was sleeping after his\r\nfatigues. He was always in a whirlwind or a calm, and a peaceable,\r\ncontented, easy-going man Mr Toodle was in either state, who seemed to\r\nhave made over all his own inheritance of fuming and fretting to the\r\nengines with which he was connected, which panted, and gasped, and\r\nchafed, and wore themselves out, in a most unsparing manner, while Mr\r\nToodle led a mild and equable life.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPolly, my gal,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mr Toodle, with a young Toodle on each knee, and\r\ntwo more making tea for him, and plenty more scattered about\xe2\x80\x94Mr Toodle\r\nwas never out of children, but always kept a good supply on hand\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cyou\r\nain\xe2\x80\x99t seen our Biler lately, have you?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Polly, \xe2\x80\x9cbut he\xe2\x80\x99s almost certain to look in tonight. It\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nhis right evening, and he\xe2\x80\x99s very regular.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI suppose,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mr Toodle, relishing his meal infinitely, \xe2\x80\x9cas our\r\nBiler is a doin\xe2\x80\x99 now about as well as a boy can do, eh, Polly?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh! he\xe2\x80\x99s a doing beautiful!\xe2\x80\x9d responded Polly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe ain\xe2\x80\x99t got to be at all secret-like\xe2\x80\x94has he, Polly?\xe2\x80\x9d inquired Mr\r\nToodle.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo!\xe2\x80\x9d said Mrs Toodle, plumply.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m glad he ain\xe2\x80\x99t got to be at all secret-like, Polly,\xe2\x80\x9d observed Mr\r\nToodle in his slow and measured way, and shovelling in his bread and\r\nbutter with a clasp knife, as if he were stoking himself, \xe2\x80\x9cbecause that\r\ndon\xe2\x80\x99t look well; do it, Polly?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy, of course it don\xe2\x80\x99t, father. How can you ask!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou see, my boys and gals,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mr Toodle, looking round upon his\r\nfamily, \xe2\x80\x9cwotever you\xe2\x80\x99re up to in a honest way, it\xe2\x80\x99s my opinion as you\r\ncan\xe2\x80\x99t do better than be open. If you find yourselves in cuttings or in\r\ntunnels, don\xe2\x80\x99t you play no secret games. Keep your whistles going, and\r\nlet\xe2\x80\x99s know where you are.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe rising Toodles set up a shrill murmur, expressive of their\r\nresolution to profit by the paternal advice.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut what makes you say this along of Rob, father?\xe2\x80\x9d asked his wife,\r\nanxiously.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPolly, old \xe2\x80\x9cooman,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mr Toodle, \xe2\x80\x9cI don\xe2\x80\x99t know as I said it\r\npartickler along o\xe2\x80\x99 Rob, I\xe2\x80\x99m sure. I starts light with Rob only; I\r\ncomes to a branch; I takes on what I finds there; and a whole train of\r\nideas gets coupled on to him, afore I knows where I am, or where they\r\ncomes from. What a Junction a man\xe2\x80\x99s thoughts is,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mr Toodle,\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cto-be-sure!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThis profound reflection Mr Toodle washed down with a pint mug of tea,\r\nand proceeded to solidify with a great weight of bread and butter;\r\ncharging his young daughters meanwhile, to keep plenty of hot water in\r\nthe pot, as he was uncommon dry, and should take the indefinite\r\nquantity of \xe2\x80\x9ca sight of mugs,\xe2\x80\x9d before his thirst was appeased.\r\n\r\nIn satisfying himself, however, Mr Toodle was not regardless of the\r\nyounger branches about him, who, although they had made their own\r\nevening repast, were on the look-out for irregular morsels, as\r\npossessing a relish. These he distributed now and then to the expectant\r\ncircle, by holding out great wedges of bread and butter, to be bitten\r\nat by the family in lawful succession, and by serving out small doses\r\nof tea in like manner with a spoon; which snacks had such a relish in\r\nthe mouths of these young Toodles, that, after partaking of the same,\r\nthey performed private dances of ecstasy among themselves, and stood on\r\none leg apiece, and hopped, and indulged in other saltatory tokens of\r\ngladness. These vents for their excitement found, they gradually closed\r\nabout Mr Toodle again, and eyed him hard as he got through more bread\r\nand butter and tea; affecting, however, to have no further expectations\r\nof their own in reference to those viands, but to be conversing on\r\nforeign subjects, and whispering confidentially.\r\n\r\nMr Toodle, in the midst of this family group, and setting an awful\r\nexample to his children in the way of appetite, was conveying the two\r\nyoung Toodles on his knees to Birmingham by special engine, and was\r\ncontemplating the rest over a barrier of bread and butter, when Rob the\r\nGrinder, in his sou\xe2\x80\x99wester hat and mourning slops, presented himself,\r\nand was received with a general rush of brothers and sisters.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, mother!\xe2\x80\x9d said Rob, dutifully kissing her; \xe2\x80\x9chow are you, mother?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThere\xe2\x80\x99s my boy!\xe2\x80\x9d cried Polly, giving him a hug and a pat on the back.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSecret! Bless you, father, not he!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThis was intended for Mr Toodle\xe2\x80\x99s private edification, but Rob the\r\nGrinder, whose withers were not unwrung, caught the words as they were\r\nspoken.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat! father\xe2\x80\x99s been a saying something more again me, has he?\xe2\x80\x9d cried\r\nthe injured innocent. \xe2\x80\x9cOh, what a hard thing it is that when a cove has\r\nonce gone a little wrong, a cove\xe2\x80\x99s own father should be always a\r\nthrowing it in his face behind his back! It\xe2\x80\x99s enough,\xe2\x80\x9d cried Rob,\r\nresorting to his coat-cuff in anguish of spirit, \xe2\x80\x9cto make a cove go and\r\ndo something, out of spite!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy poor boy!\xe2\x80\x9d cried Polly, \xe2\x80\x9cfather didn\xe2\x80\x99t mean anything.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf father didn\xe2\x80\x99t mean anything,\xe2\x80\x9d blubbered the injured Grinder, \xe2\x80\x9cwhy\r\ndid he go and say anything, mother? Nobody thinks half so bad of me as\r\nmy own father does. What a unnatural thing! I wish somebody\xe2\x80\x99d take and\r\nchop my head off. Father wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t mind doing it, I believe, and I\xe2\x80\x99d\r\nmuch rather he did that than t\xe2\x80\x99other.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAt these desperate words all the young Toodles shrieked; a pathetic\r\neffect, which the Grinder improved by ironically adjuring them not to\r\ncry for him, for they ought to hate him, they ought, if they was good\r\nboys and girls; and this so touched the youngest Toodle but one, who\r\nwas easily moved, that it touched him not only in his spirit but in his\r\nwind too; making him so purple that Mr Toodle in consternation carried\r\nhim out to the water-butt, and would have put him under the tap, but\r\nfor his being recovered by the sight of that instrument.\r\n\r\nMatters having reached this point, Mr Toodle explained, and the\r\nvirtuous feelings of his son being thereby calmed, they shook hands,\r\nand harmony reigned again.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWill you do as I do, Biler, my boy?\xe2\x80\x9d inquired his father, returning to\r\nhis tea with new strength.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, thank\xe2\x80\x99ee, father. Master and I had tea together.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd how _is_ master, Rob?\xe2\x80\x9d said Polly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, I don\xe2\x80\x99t know, mother; not much to boast on. There ain\xe2\x80\x99t no\r\nbis\xe2\x80\x99ness done, you see. He don\xe2\x80\x99t know anything about it\xe2\x80\x94the Cap\xe2\x80\x99en\r\ndon\xe2\x80\x99t. There was a man come into the shop this very day, and says, \xe2\x80\x98I\r\nwant a so-and-so,\xe2\x80\x99 he says\xe2\x80\x94some hard name or another. \xe2\x80\x98A which?\xe2\x80\x99 says\r\nthe Cap\xe2\x80\x99en. \xe2\x80\x98A so-and-so,\xe2\x80\x99 says the man. \xe2\x80\x98Brother,\xe2\x80\x99 says the Cap\xe2\x80\x99en,\r\n\xe2\x80\x98will you take a observation round the shop.\xe2\x80\x99 \xe2\x80\x98Well,\xe2\x80\x99 says the man,\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I\xe2\x80\x99ve done.\xe2\x80\x99 \xe2\x80\x98Do you see wot you want?\xe2\x80\x99 says the Cap\xe2\x80\x99en \xe2\x80\x98No, I don\xe2\x80\x99t,\xe2\x80\x99\r\nsays the man. \xe2\x80\x98Do you know it wen you _do_ see it?\xe2\x80\x99 says the Cap\xe2\x80\x99en.\r\n\xe2\x80\x98No, I don\xe2\x80\x99t,\xe2\x80\x99 says the man. \xe2\x80\x98Why, then I tell you wot, my lad,\xe2\x80\x99 says\r\nthe Cap\xe2\x80\x99en, \xe2\x80\x98you\xe2\x80\x99d better go back and ask wot it\xe2\x80\x99s like, outside, for\r\nno more don\xe2\x80\x99t I!\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat ain\xe2\x80\x99t the way to make money, though, is it?\xe2\x80\x9d said Polly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMoney, mother! He\xe2\x80\x99ll never make money. He has such ways as I never\r\nsee. He ain\xe2\x80\x99t a bad master though, I\xe2\x80\x99ll say that for him. But that\r\nain\xe2\x80\x99t much to me, for I don\xe2\x80\x99t think I shall stop with him long.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNot stop in your place, Rob!\xe2\x80\x9d cried his mother; while Mr Toodle opened\r\nhis eyes.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNot in that place, p\xe2\x80\x99raps,\xe2\x80\x9d returned the Grinder, with a wink. \xe2\x80\x9cI\r\nshouldn\xe2\x80\x99t wonder\xe2\x80\x94friends at court you know\xe2\x80\x94but never _you_ mind,\r\nmother, just now; I\xe2\x80\x99m all right, that\xe2\x80\x99s all.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe indisputable proof afforded in these hints, and in the Grinder\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nmysterious manner, of his not being subject to that failing which Mr\r\nToodle had, by implication, attributed to him, might have led to a\r\nrenewal of his wrongs, and of the sensation in the family, but for the\r\nopportune arrival of another visitor, who, to Polly\xe2\x80\x99s great surprise,\r\nappeared at the door, smiling patronage and friendship on all there.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow do you do, Mrs Richards?\xe2\x80\x9d said Miss Tox. \xe2\x80\x9cI have come to see you.\r\nMay I come in?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe cheery face of Mrs Richards shone with a hospitable reply, and Miss\r\nTox, accepting the proffered chair, and gracefully recognising Mr\r\nToodle on her way to it, untied her bonnet strings, and said that in\r\nthe first place she must beg the dear children, one and all, to come\r\nand kiss her.\r\n\r\n[Illustration]\r\n\r\nThe ill-starred youngest Toodle but one, who would appear, from the\r\nfrequency of his domestic troubles, to have been born under an unlucky\r\nplanet, was prevented from performing his part in this general\r\nsalutation by having fixed the sou\xe2\x80\x99wester hat (with which he had been\r\npreviously trifling) deep on his head, hind side before, and being\r\nunable to get it off again; which accident presenting to his terrified\r\nimagination a dismal picture of his passing the rest of his days in\r\ndarkness, and in hopeless seclusion from his friends and family, caused\r\nhim to struggle with great violence, and to utter suffocating cries.\r\nBeing released, his face was discovered to be very hot, and red, and\r\ndamp; and Miss Tox took him on her lap, much exhausted.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou have almost forgotten me, Sir, I daresay,\xe2\x80\x9d said Miss Tox to Mr\r\nToodle.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, Ma\xe2\x80\x99am, no,\xe2\x80\x9d said Toodle. \xe2\x80\x9cBut we\xe2\x80\x99ve all on us got a little older\r\nsince then.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd how do you find yourself, Sir?\xe2\x80\x9d inquired Miss Tox, blandly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHearty, Ma\xe2\x80\x99am, thank\xe2\x80\x99ee,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Toodle. \xe2\x80\x9cHow do _you_ find\r\n_your_self, Ma\xe2\x80\x99am? Do the rheumaticks keep off pretty well, Ma\xe2\x80\x99am? We\r\nmust all expect to grow into \xe2\x80\x99em, as we gets on.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThank you,\xe2\x80\x9d said Miss Tox. \xe2\x80\x9cI have not felt any inconvenience from\r\nthat disorder yet.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou\xe2\x80\x99re wery fortunate, Ma\xe2\x80\x99am,\xe2\x80\x9d returned Mr Toodle. \xe2\x80\x9cMany people at\r\nyour time of life, Ma\xe2\x80\x99am, is martyrs to it. There was my mother\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d But\r\ncatching his wife\xe2\x80\x99s eye here, Mr Toodle judiciously buried the rest in\r\nanother mug of tea.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou never mean to say, Mrs Richards,\xe2\x80\x9d cried Miss Tox, looking at Rob,\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cthat that is your\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cEldest, Ma\xe2\x80\x99am,\xe2\x80\x9d said Polly. \xe2\x80\x9cYes, indeed, it is. That\xe2\x80\x99s the little\r\nfellow, Ma\xe2\x80\x99am, that was the innocent cause of so much.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThis here, Ma\xe2\x80\x99am,\xe2\x80\x9d said Toodle, \xe2\x80\x9cis him with the short legs\xe2\x80\x94and they\r\nwas,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mr Toodle, with a touch of poetry in his tone, \xe2\x80\x9cunusual\r\nshort for leathers\xe2\x80\x94as Mr Dombey made a Grinder on.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe recollection almost overpowered Miss Tox. The subject of it had a\r\npeculiar interest for her directly. She asked him to shake hands, and\r\ncongratulated his mother on his frank, ingenuous face. Rob, overhearing\r\nher, called up a look, to justify the eulogium, but it was hardly the\r\nright look.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd now, Mrs Richards,\xe2\x80\x9d said Miss Tox,\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cand you too, Sir,\xe2\x80\x9d addressing\r\nToodle\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ll tell you, plainly and truly, what I have come here for.\r\nYou may be aware, Mrs Richards\xe2\x80\x94and, possibly, you may be aware too,\r\nSir\xe2\x80\x94that a little distance has interposed itself between me and some of\r\nmy friends, and that where I used to visit a good deal, I do not visit\r\nnow.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nPolly, who, with a woman\xe2\x80\x99s tact, understood this at once, expressed as\r\nmuch in a little look. Mr Toodle, who had not the faintest idea of what\r\nMiss Tox was talking about, expressed that also, in a stare.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOf course,\xe2\x80\x9d said Miss Tox, \xe2\x80\x9chow our little coolness has arisen is of\r\nno moment, and does not require to be discussed. It is sufficient for\r\nme to say, that I have the greatest possible respect for, and interest\r\nin, Mr Dombey;\xe2\x80\x9d Miss Tox\xe2\x80\x99s voice faltered; \xe2\x80\x9cand everything that relates\r\nto him.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMr Toodle, enlightened, shook his head, and said he had heerd it said,\r\nand, for his own part, he did think, as Mr Dombey was a difficult\r\nsubject.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPray don\xe2\x80\x99t say so, Sir, if you please,\xe2\x80\x9d returned Miss Tox. \xe2\x80\x9cLet me\r\nentreat you not to say so, Sir, either now, or at any future time. Such\r\nobservations cannot but be very painful to me; and to a gentleman,\r\nwhose mind is constituted as, I am quite sure, yours is, can afford no\r\npermanent satisfaction.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMr Toodle, who had not entertained the least doubt of offering a remark\r\nthat would be received with acquiescence, was greatly confounded.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAll that I wish to say, Mrs Richards,\xe2\x80\x9d resumed Miss Tox,\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cand I\r\naddress myself to you too, Sir,\xe2\x80\x94is this. That any intelligence of the\r\nproceedings of the family, of the welfare of the family, of the health\r\nof the family, that reaches you, will be always most acceptable to me.\r\nThat I shall be always very glad to chat with Mrs Richards about the\r\nfamily, and about old time. And as Mrs Richards and I never had the\r\nleast difference (though I could wish now that we had been better\r\nacquainted, but I have no one but myself to blame for that), I hope she\r\nwill not object to our being very good friends now, and to my coming\r\nbackwards and forwards here, when I like, without being a stranger.\r\nNow, I really hope, Mrs Richards,\xe2\x80\x9d said Miss Tox, earnestly, \xe2\x80\x9cthat you\r\nwill take this, as I mean it, like a good-humoured creature, as you\r\nalways were.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nPolly was gratified, and showed it. Mr Toodle didn\xe2\x80\x99t know whether he\r\nwas gratified or not, and preserved a stolid calmness.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou see, Mrs Richards,\xe2\x80\x9d said Miss Tox\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cand I hope you see too,\r\nSir\xe2\x80\x94there are many little ways in which I can be slightly useful to\r\nyou, if you will make no stranger of me; and in which I shall be\r\ndelighted to be so. For instance, I can teach your children something.\r\nI shall bring a few little books, if you\xe2\x80\x99ll allow me, and some work,\r\nand of an evening now and then, they\xe2\x80\x99ll learn\xe2\x80\x94dear me, they\xe2\x80\x99ll learn a\r\ngreat deal, I trust, and be a credit to their teacher.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMr Toodle, who had a great respect for learning, jerked his head\r\napprovingly at his wife, and moistened his hands with dawning\r\nsatisfaction.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen, not being a stranger, I shall be in nobody\xe2\x80\x99s way,\xe2\x80\x9d said Miss\r\nTox, \xe2\x80\x9cand everything will go on just as if I were not here. Mrs\r\nRichards will do her mending, or her ironing, or her nursing, whatever\r\nit is, without minding me: and you\xe2\x80\x99ll smoke your pipe, too, if you\xe2\x80\x99re\r\nso disposed, Sir, won\xe2\x80\x99t you?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThank\xe2\x80\x99ee, Mum,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mr Toodle. \xe2\x80\x9cYes; I\xe2\x80\x99ll take my bit of backer.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cVery good of you to say so, Sir,\xe2\x80\x9d rejoined Miss Tox, \xe2\x80\x9cand I really do\r\nassure you now, unfeignedly, that it will be a great comfort to me, and\r\nthat whatever good I may be fortunate enough to do the children, you\r\nwill more than pay back to me, if you\xe2\x80\x99ll enter into this little bargain\r\ncomfortably, and easily, and good-naturedly, without another word about\r\nit.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe bargain was ratified on the spot; and Miss Tox found herself so\r\nmuch at home already, that without delay she instituted a preliminary\r\nexamination of the children all round\xe2\x80\x94which Mr Toodle much admired\xe2\x80\x94and\r\nbooked their ages, names, and acquirements, on a piece of paper. This\r\nceremony, and a little attendant gossip, prolonged the time until after\r\ntheir usual hour of going to bed, and detained Miss Tox at the Toodle\r\nfireside until it was too late for her to walk home alone. The gallant\r\nGrinder, however, being still there, politely offered to attend her to\r\nher own door; and as it was something to Miss Tox to be seen home by a\r\nyouth whom Mr Dombey had first inducted into those manly garments which\r\nare rarely mentioned by name, she very readily accepted the proposal.\r\n\r\nAfter shaking hands with Mr Toodle and Polly, and kissing all the\r\nchildren, Miss Tox left the house, therefore, with unlimited\r\npopularity, and carrying away with her so light a heart that it might\r\nhave given Mrs Chick offence if that good lady could have weighed it.\r\n\r\nRob the Grinder, in his modesty, would have walked behind, but Miss Tox\r\ndesired him to keep beside her, for conversational purposes; and, as\r\nshe afterwards expressed it to his mother, \xe2\x80\x9cdrew him out,\xe2\x80\x9d upon the\r\nroad.\r\n\r\nHe drew out so bright, and clear, and shining, that Miss Tox was\r\ncharmed with him. The more Miss Tox drew him out, the finer he\r\ncame\xe2\x80\x94like wire. There never was a better or more promising youth\xe2\x80\x94a more\r\naffectionate, steady, prudent, sober, honest, meek, candid young\r\nman\xe2\x80\x94than Rob drew out, that night.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am quite glad,\xe2\x80\x9d said Miss Tox, arrived at her own door, \xe2\x80\x9cto know\r\nyou. I hope you\xe2\x80\x99ll consider me your friend, and that you\xe2\x80\x99ll come and\r\nsee me as often as you like. Do you keep a money-box?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, Ma\xe2\x80\x99am,\xe2\x80\x9d returned Rob; \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m saving up, against I\xe2\x80\x99ve got enough to\r\nput in the Bank, Ma\xe2\x80\x99am.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cVery laudable indeed,\xe2\x80\x9d said Miss Tox. \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m glad to hear it. Put this\r\nhalf-crown into it, if you please.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh thank you, Ma\xe2\x80\x99am,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Rob, \xe2\x80\x9cbut really I couldn\xe2\x80\x99t think of\r\ndepriving you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI commend your independent spirit,\xe2\x80\x9d said Miss Tox, \xe2\x80\x9cbut it\xe2\x80\x99s no\r\ndeprivation, I assure you. I shall be offended if you don\xe2\x80\x99t take it, as\r\na mark of my good-will. Good-night, Robin.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGood-night, Ma\xe2\x80\x99am,\xe2\x80\x9d said Rob, \xe2\x80\x9cand thank you!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nWho ran sniggering off to get change, and tossed it away with a pieman.\r\nBut they never taught honour at the Grinders\xe2\x80\x99 School, where the system\r\nthat prevailed was particularly strong in the engendering of hypocrisy.\r\nInsomuch, that many of the friends and masters of past Grinders said,\r\nif this were what came of education for the common people, let us have\r\nnone. Some more rational said, let us have a better one. But the\r\ngoverning powers of the Grinders\xe2\x80\x99 Company were always ready for them,\r\nby picking out a few boys who had turned out well in spite of the\r\nsystem, and roundly asserting that they could have only turned out well\r\nbecause of it. Which settled the business of those objectors out of\r\nhand, and established the glory of the Grinders\xe2\x80\x99 Institution.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER XXXIX.\r\nFurther Adventures of Captain Edward Cuttle, Mariner\r\n\r\n\r\nTime, sure of foot and strong of will, had so pressed onward, that the\r\nyear enjoined by the old Instrument-maker, as the term during which his\r\nfriend should refrain from opening the sealed packet accompanying the\r\nletter he had left for him, was now nearly expired, and Captain Cuttle\r\nbegan to look at it, of an evening, with feelings of mystery and\r\nuneasiness.\r\n\r\nThe Captain, in his honour, would as soon have thought of opening the\r\nparcel one hour before the expiration of the term, as he would have\r\nthought of opening himself, to study his own anatomy. He merely brought\r\nit out, at a certain stage of his first evening pipe, laid it on the\r\ntable, and sat gazing at the outside of it, through the smoke, in\r\nsilent gravity, for two or three hours at a spell. Sometimes, when he\r\nhad contemplated it thus for a pretty long while, the Captain would\r\nhitch his chair, by degrees, farther and farther off, as if to get\r\nbeyond the range of its fascination; but if this were his design, he\r\nnever succeeded: for even when he was brought up by the parlour wall,\r\nthe packet still attracted him; or if his eyes, in thoughtful\r\nwandering, roved to the ceiling or the fire, its image immediately\r\nfollowed, and posted itself conspicuously among the coals, or took up\r\nan advantageous position on the whitewash.\r\n\r\nIn respect of Heart\xe2\x80\x99s Delight, the Captain\xe2\x80\x99s parental and admiration\r\nknew no change. But since his last interview with Mr Carker, Captain\r\nCuttle had come to entertain doubts whether his former intervention in\r\nbehalf of that young lady and his dear boy Wal\xe2\x80\x9dr, had proved altogether\r\nso favourable as he could have wished, and as he at the time believed.\r\nThe Captain was troubled with a serious misgiving that he had done more\r\nharm than good, in short; and in his remorse and modesty he made the\r\nbest atonement he could think of, by putting himself out of the way of\r\ndoing any harm to anyone, and, as it were, throwing himself overboard\r\nfor a dangerous person.\r\n\r\nSelf-buried, therefore, among the instruments, the Captain never went\r\nnear Mr Dombey\xe2\x80\x99s house, or reported himself in any way to Florence or\r\nMiss Nipper. He even severed himself from Mr Perch, on the occasion of\r\nhis next visit, by dryly informing that gentleman, that he thanked him\r\nfor his company, but had cut himself adrift from all such acquaintance,\r\nas he didn\xe2\x80\x99t know what magazine he mightn\xe2\x80\x99t blow up, without meaning of\r\nit. In this self-imposed retirement, the Captain passed whole days and\r\nweeks without interchanging a word with anyone but Rob the Grinder,\r\nwhom he esteemed as a pattern of disinterested attachment and fidelity.\r\nIn this retirement, the Captain, gazing at the packet of an evening,\r\nwould sit smoking, and thinking of Florence and poor Walter, until they\r\nboth seemed to his homely fancy to be dead, and to have passed away\r\ninto eternal youth, the beautiful and innocent children of his first\r\nremembrance.\r\n\r\nThe Captain did not, however, in his musings, neglect his own\r\nimprovement, or the mental culture of Rob the Grinder. That young man\r\nwas generally required to read out of some book to the Captain, for one\r\nhour, every evening; and as the Captain implicitly believed that all\r\nbooks were true, he accumulated, by this means, many remarkable facts.\r\nOn Sunday nights, the Captain always read for himself, before going to\r\nbed, a certain Divine Sermon once delivered on a Mount; and although he\r\nwas accustomed to quote the text, without book, after his own manner,\r\nhe appeared to read it with as reverent an understanding of its\r\nheavenly spirit, as if he had got it all by heart in Greek, and had\r\nbeen able to write any number of fierce theological disquisitions on\r\nits every phrase.\r\n\r\nRob the Grinder, whose reverence for the inspired writings, under the\r\nadmirable system of the Grinders\xe2\x80\x99 School, had been developed by a\r\nperpetual bruising of his intellectual shins against all the proper\r\nnames of all the tribes of Judah, and by the monotonous repetition of\r\nhard verses, especially by way of punishment, and by the parading of\r\nhim at six years old in leather breeches, three times a Sunday, very\r\nhigh up, in a very hot church, with a great organ buzzing against his\r\ndrowsy head, like an exceedingly busy bee\xe2\x80\x94Rob the Grinder made a mighty\r\nshow of being edified when the Captain ceased to read, and generally\r\nyawned and nodded while the reading was in progress. The latter fact\r\nbeing never so much as suspected by the good Captain.\r\n\r\nCaptain Cuttle, also, as a man of business; took to keeping books. In\r\nthese he entered observations on the weather, and on the currents of\r\nthe waggons and other vehicles: which he observed, in that quarter, to\r\nset westward in the morning and during the greater part of the day, and\r\neastward towards the evening. Two or three stragglers appearing in one\r\nweek, who \xe2\x80\x9cspoke him\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94so the Captain entered it\xe2\x80\x94on the subject of\r\nspectacles, and who, without positively purchasing, said they would\r\nlook in again, the Captain decided that the business was improving, and\r\nmade an entry in the day-book to that effect: the wind then blowing\r\n(which he first recorded) pretty fresh, west and by north; having\r\nchanged in the night.\r\n\r\nOne of the Captain\xe2\x80\x99s chief difficulties was Mr Toots, who called\r\nfrequently, and who without saying much seemed to have an idea that the\r\nlittle back parlour was an eligible room to chuckle in, as he would sit\r\nand avail himself of its accommodations in that regard by the half-hour\r\ntogether, without at all advancing in intimacy with the Captain. The\r\nCaptain, rendered cautious by his late experience, was unable quite to\r\nsatisfy his mind whether Mr Toots was the mild subject he appeared to\r\nbe, or was a profoundly artful and dissimulating hypocrite. His\r\nfrequent reference to Miss Dombey was suspicious; but the Captain had a\r\nsecret kindness for Mr Toots\xe2\x80\x99s apparent reliance on him, and forbore to\r\ndecide against him for the present; merely eyeing him, with a sagacity\r\nnot to be described, whenever he approached the subject that was\r\nnearest to his heart.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCaptain Gills,\xe2\x80\x9d blurted out Mr Toots, one day all at once, as his\r\nmanner was, \xe2\x80\x9cdo you think you could think favourably of that\r\nproposition of mine, and give me the pleasure of your acquaintance?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy, I tell you what it is, my lad,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the Captain, who had at\r\nlength concluded on a course of action; \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ve been turning that there,\r\nover.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCaptain Gills, it\xe2\x80\x99s very kind of you,\xe2\x80\x9d retorted Mr Toots. \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m much\r\nobliged to you. Upon my word and honour, Captain Gills, it would be a\r\ncharity to give me the pleasure of your acquaintance. It really would.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou see, brother,\xe2\x80\x9d argued the Captain slowly, \xe2\x80\x9cI don\xe2\x80\x99t know you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut you never can know me, Captain Gills,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Mr Toots, steadfast\r\nto his point, \xe2\x80\x9cif you don\xe2\x80\x99t give me the pleasure of your acquaintance.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe Captain seemed struck by the originality and power of this remark,\r\nand looked at Mr Toots as if he thought there was a great deal more in\r\nhim than he had expected.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell said, my lad,\xe2\x80\x9d observed the Captain, nodding his head\r\nthoughtfully; \xe2\x80\x9cand true. Now look\xe2\x80\x99ee here: You\xe2\x80\x99ve made some\r\nobservations to me, which gives me to understand as you admire a\r\ncertain sweet creetur. Hey?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCaptain Gills,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mr Toots, gesticulating violently with the hand\r\nin which he held his hat, \xe2\x80\x9cAdmiration is not the word. Upon my honour,\r\nyou have no conception what my feelings are. If I could be dyed black,\r\nand made Miss Dombey\xe2\x80\x99s slave, I should consider it a compliment. If, at\r\nthe sacrifice of all my property, I could get transmigrated into Miss\r\nDombey\xe2\x80\x99s dog\xe2\x80\x94I\xe2\x80\x94I really think I should never leave off wagging my tail.\r\nI should be so perfectly happy, Captain Gills!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMr Toots said it with watery eyes, and pressed his hat against his\r\nbosom with deep emotion.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy lad,\xe2\x80\x9d returned the Captain, moved to compassion, \xe2\x80\x9cif you\xe2\x80\x99re in\r\narnest\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCaptain Gills,\xe2\x80\x9d cried Mr Toots, \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m in such a state of mind, and am\r\nso dreadfully in earnest, that if I could swear to it upon a hot piece\r\nof iron, or a live coal, or melted lead, or burning sealing-wax, Or\r\nanything of that sort, I should be glad to hurt myself, as a relief to\r\nmy feelings.\xe2\x80\x9d And Mr Toots looked hurriedly about the room, as if for\r\nsome sufficiently painful means of accomplishing his dread purpose.\r\n\r\nThe Captain pushed his glazed hat back upon his head, stroked his face\r\ndown with his heavy hand\xe2\x80\x94making his nose more mottled in the\r\nprocess\xe2\x80\x94and planting himself before Mr Toots, and hooking him by the\r\nlapel of his coat, addressed him in these words, while Mr Toots looked\r\nup into his face, with much attention and some wonder.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf you\xe2\x80\x99re in arnest, you see, my lad,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Captain, \xe2\x80\x9cyou\xe2\x80\x99re a\r\nobject of clemency, and clemency is the brightest jewel in the crown of\r\na Briton\xe2\x80\x99s head, for which you\xe2\x80\x99ll overhaul the constitution as laid\r\ndown in Rule Britannia, and, when found, that is the charter as them\r\ngarden angels was a singing of, so many times over. Stand by! This here\r\nproposal o\xe2\x80\x99 you\xe2\x80\x99rn takes me a little aback. And why? Because I holds my\r\nown only, you understand, in these here waters, and haven\xe2\x80\x99t got no\r\nconsort, and may be don\xe2\x80\x99t wish for none. Steady! You hailed me first,\r\nalong of a certain young lady, as you was chartered by. Now if you and\r\nme is to keep one another\xe2\x80\x99s company at all, that there young creetur\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nname must never be named nor referred to. I don\xe2\x80\x99t know what harm mayn\xe2\x80\x99t\r\nhave been done by naming of it too free, afore now, and thereby I\r\nbrings up short. D\xe2\x80\x99ye make me out pretty clear, brother?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, you\xe2\x80\x99ll excuse me, Captain Gills,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Mr Toots, \xe2\x80\x9cif I don\xe2\x80\x99t\r\nquite follow you sometimes. But upon my word I\xe2\x80\x94it\xe2\x80\x99s a hard thing,\r\nCaptain Gills, not to be able to mention Miss Dombey. I really have got\r\nsuch a dreadful load here!\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94Mr Toots pathetically touched his\r\nshirt-front with both hands\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cthat I feel night and day, exactly as if\r\nsomebody was sitting upon me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThem,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Captain, \xe2\x80\x9cis the terms I offer. If they\xe2\x80\x99re hard upon\r\nyou, brother, as mayhap they are, give \xe2\x80\x99em a wide berth, sheer off, and\r\npart company cheerily!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCaptain Gills,\xe2\x80\x9d returned Mr Toots, \xe2\x80\x9cI hardly know how it is, but after\r\nwhat you told me when I came here, for the first time, I\xe2\x80\x94I feel that\r\nI\xe2\x80\x99d rather think about Miss Dombey in your society than talk about her\r\nin almost anybody else\xe2\x80\x99s. Therefore, Captain Gills, if you\xe2\x80\x99ll give me\r\nthe pleasure of your acquaintance, I shall be very happy to accept it\r\non your own conditions. I wish to be honourable, Captain Gills,\xe2\x80\x9d said\r\nMr Toots, holding back his extended hand for a moment, \xe2\x80\x9cand therefore I\r\nam obliged to say that I can not help thinking about Miss Dombey. It\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nimpossible for me to make a promise not to think about her.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy lad,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Captain, whose opinion of Mr Toots was much improved\r\nby this candid avowal, \xe2\x80\x9ca man\xe2\x80\x99s thoughts is like the winds, and nobody\r\ncan\xe2\x80\x99t answer for \xe2\x80\x99em for certain, any length of time together. Mr Toots seemed much relieved and\r\ngladdened by the acquisition, and chuckled rapturously during the\r\nremainder of his visit. The Captain, for his part, was not ill pleased\r\nto occupy that position of patronage, and was exceedingly well\r\nsatisfied by his own prudence and foresight.\r\n\r\nBut rich as Captain Cuttle was in the latter quality, he received a\r\nsurprise that same evening from a no less ingenuous and simple youth,\r\nthan Rob the Grinder. That artless lad, drinking tea at the same table,\r\nand bending meekly over his cup and saucer, having taken sidelong\r\nobservations of his master for some time, who was reading the newspaper\r\nwith great difficulty, but much dignity, through his glasses, broke\r\nsilence by saying\xe2\x80\x94\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh! I beg your pardon, Captain, but you mayn\xe2\x80\x99t be in want of any\r\npigeons, may you, Sir?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, my lad,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the Captain.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBecause I was wishing to dispose of mine, Captain,\xe2\x80\x9d said Rob.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAy, ay?\xe2\x80\x9d cried the Captain, lifting up his bushy eyebrows a little.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes; I\xe2\x80\x99m going, Captain, if you please,\xe2\x80\x9d said Rob.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGoing? I thought you\xe2\x80\x99d have\r\nknown that beforehand, perhaps,\xe2\x80\x9d said Rob, rubbing his hands, and\r\ngetting up. \xe2\x80\x9cIf you could be so good as provide yourself soon, Captain,\r\nit would be a great convenience to me. You couldn\xe2\x80\x99t provide yourself by\r\nto-morrow morning, I am afraid, Captain: could you, do you think?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd you\xe2\x80\x99re a going to desert your colours, are you, my lad?\xe2\x80\x9d said the\r\nCaptain, after a long examination of his face.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, it\xe2\x80\x99s very hard upon a cove, Captain,\xe2\x80\x9d cried the tender Rob,\r\ninjured and indignant in a moment, \xe2\x80\x9cthat he can\xe2\x80\x99t give lawful warning,\r\nwithout being frowned at in that way, and called a deserter. You\r\nhaven\xe2\x80\x99t any right to call a poor cove names, Captain. It ain\xe2\x80\x99t because\r\nI\xe2\x80\x99m a servant and you\xe2\x80\x99re a master, that you\xe2\x80\x99re to go and libel me. What\r\nwrong have I done? Come, Captain, let me know what my crime is, will\r\nyou?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe stricken Grinder wept, and put his coat-cuff in his eye.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCome, Captain,\xe2\x80\x9d cried the injured youth, \xe2\x80\x9cgive my crime a name! What\r\nhave I been and done? Have I stolen any of the property? have I set the\r\nhouse a-fire? If I have, why don\xe2\x80\x99t you give me in charge, and try it?\r\nBut to take away the character of a lad that\xe2\x80\x99s been a good servant to\r\nyou, because he can\xe2\x80\x99t afford to stand in his own light for your good,\r\nwhat a injury it is, and what a bad return for faithful service! This\r\nis the way young coves is spiled and drove wrong. I wonder at you,\r\nCaptain, I do.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAll of which the Grinder howled forth in a lachrymose whine, and\r\nbacking carefully towards the door.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd so you\xe2\x80\x99ve got another berth, have you, my lad?\xe2\x80\x9d said the Captain,\r\neyeing him intently.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, Captain, since you put it in that shape, I have got another\r\nberth,\xe2\x80\x9d cried Rob, backing more and more; \xe2\x80\x9ca better berth than I\xe2\x80\x99ve got\r\nhere, and one where I don\xe2\x80\x99t so much as want your good word, Captain,\r\nwhich is fort\xe2\x80\x99nate for me, after all the dirt you\xe2\x80\x99ve throw\xe2\x80\x99d at me,\r\nbecause I\xe2\x80\x99m poor, and can\xe2\x80\x99t afford to stand in my own light for your\r\ngood. Yes, I have got another berth; and if it wasn\xe2\x80\x99t for leaving you\r\nunprovided, Captain, I\xe2\x80\x99d go to it now, sooner than I\xe2\x80\x99d take them names\r\nfrom you, because I\xe2\x80\x99m poor, and can\xe2\x80\x99t afford to stand in my own light\r\nfor your good. Why do you reproach me for being poor, and not standing\r\nin my own light for your good, Captain? How can you so demean\r\nyourself?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLook ye here, my boy,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the peaceful Captain. \xe2\x80\x9cDon\xe2\x80\x99t you pay\r\nout no more of them words.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, then, don\xe2\x80\x99t you pay in no more of your words, Captain,\xe2\x80\x9d retorted\r\nthe roused innocent, getting louder in his whine, and backing into the\r\nshop. \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99d sooner you took my blood than my character.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBecause,\xe2\x80\x9d pursued the Captain calmly, \xe2\x80\x9cyou have heerd, may be, of such\r\na thing as a rope\xe2\x80\x99s end.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, have I though, Captain?\xe2\x80\x9d cried the taunting Grinder. \xe2\x80\x9cNo I\r\nhaven\xe2\x80\x99t. I never heerd of any such a article!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Captain, \xe2\x80\x9cit\xe2\x80\x99s my belief as you\xe2\x80\x99ll know more about it\r\npretty soon, if you don\xe2\x80\x99t keep a bright look-out. I can read your\r\nsignals, my lad. You may go.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh! I may go at once, may I, Captain?\xe2\x80\x9d cried Rob, exulting in his\r\nsuccess. \xe2\x80\x9cBut mind! And you\xe2\x80\x99re not to stop any of my wages, Captain!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHis employer settled the last point by producing the tin canister and\r\ntelling the Grinder\xe2\x80\x99s money out in full upon the table. Rob, snivelling\r\nand sobbing, and grievously wounded in his feelings, took up the pieces\r\none by one, with a sob and a snivel for each, and tied them up\r\nseparately in knots in his pockethandkerchief; then he ascended to the\r\nroof of the house and filled his hat and pockets with pigeons; then,\r\ncame down to his bed under the counter and made up his bundle,\r\nsnivelling and sobbing louder, as if he were cut to the heart by old\r\nassociations; then he whined, \xe2\x80\x9cGood-night, Captain. I leave you without\r\nmalice!\xe2\x80\x9d and then, going out upon the door-step, pulled the little\r\nMidshipman\xe2\x80\x99s nose as a parting indignity, and went away down the street\r\ngrinning triumphantly.\r\n\r\nThe Captain, left to himself, resumed his perusal of the news as if\r\nnothing unusual or unexpected had taken place, and went reading on with\r\nthe greatest assiduity. But never a word did Captain Cuttle understand,\r\nthough he read a vast number, for Rob the Grinder was scampering up one\r\ncolumn and down another all through the newspaper.\r\n\r\nIt is doubtful whether the worthy Captain had ever felt himself quite\r\nabandoned until now; but now, old Sol Gills, Walter, and Heart\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nDelight were lost to him indeed, and now Mr Carker deceived and jeered\r\nhim cruelly. They were all represented in the false Rob, to whom he had\r\nheld forth many a time on the recollections that were warm within him;\r\nhe had believed in the false Rob, and had been glad to believe in him;\r\nhe had made a companion of him as the last of the old ship\xe2\x80\x99s company;\r\nhe had taken the command of the little Midshipman with him at his right\r\nhand; he had meant to do his duty by him, and had felt almost as kindly\r\ntowards the boy as if they had been shipwrecked and cast upon a desert\r\nplace together. And now, that the false Rob had brought distrust,\r\ntreachery, and meanness into the very parlour, which was a kind of\r\nsacred place, Captain Cuttle felt as if the parlour might have gone\r\ndown next, and not surprised him much by its sinking, or given him any\r\nvery great concern.\r\n\r\nTherefore Captain Cuttle read the newspaper with profound attention and\r\nno comprehension, and therefore Captain Cuttle said nothing whatever\r\nabout Rob to himself, or admitted to himself that he was thinking about\r\nhim, or would recognise in the most distant manner that Rob had\r\nanything to do with his feeling as lonely as Robinson Crusoe.\r\n\r\nIn the same composed, business-like way, the Captain stepped over to\r\nLeadenhall Market in the dusk, and effected an arrangement with a\r\nprivate watchman on duty there, to come and put up and take down the\r\nshutters of the wooden Midshipman every night and morning. He then\r\ncalled in at the eating-house to diminish by one half the daily rations\r\ntheretofore supplied to the Midshipman, and at the public-house to stop\r\nthe traitor\xe2\x80\x99s beer. \xe2\x80\x9cMy young man,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Captain, in explanation to\r\nthe young lady at the bar, \xe2\x80\x9cmy young man having bettered himself,\r\nMiss.\xe2\x80\x9d Lastly, the Captain resolved to take possession of the bed under\r\nthe counter, and to turn in there o\xe2\x80\x99 nights instead of upstairs, as\r\nsole guardian of the property.\r\n\r\nFrom this bed Captain Cuttle daily rose thenceforth, and clapped on his\r\nglazed hat at six o\xe2\x80\x99clock in the morning, with the solitary air of\r\nCrusoe finishing his toilet with his goat-skin cap; and although his\r\nfears of a visitation from the savage tribe, MacStinger, were somewhat\r\ncooled, as similar apprehensions on the part of that lone mariner used\r\nto be by the lapse of a long interval without any symptoms of the\r\ncannibals, he still observed a regular routine of defensive operations,\r\nand never encountered a bonnet without previous survey from his castle\r\nof retreat. In the meantime (during which he received no call from Mr\r\nToots, who wrote to say he was out of town) his own voice began to have\r\na strange sound in his ears; and he acquired such habits of profound\r\nmeditation from much polishing and stowing away of the stock, and from\r\nmuch sitting behind the counter reading, or looking out of window, that\r\nthe red rim made on his forehead by the hard glazed hat, sometimes\r\nached again with excess of reflection.\r\n\r\nThe year being now expired, Captain Cuttle deemed it expedient to open\r\nthe packet; but as he had always designed doing this in the presence of\r\nRob the Grinder, who had brought it to him, and as he had an idea that\r\nit would be regular and ship-shape to open it in the presence of\r\nsomebody, he was sadly put to it for want of a witness. In this\r\ndifficulty, he hailed one day with unusual delight the announcement in\r\nthe Shipping Intelligence of the arrival of the Cautious Clara, Captain\r\nJohn Bunsby, from a coasting voyage; and to that philosopher\r\nimmediately dispatched a letter by post, enjoining inviolable secrecy\r\nas to his place of residence, and requesting to be favoured with an\r\nearly visit, in the evening season.\r\n\r\nBunsby, who was one of those sages who act upon conviction, took some\r\ndays to get the conviction thoroughly into his mind, that he had\r\nreceived a letter to this effect. But when he had grappled with the\r\nfact, and mastered it, he promptly sent his boy with the message, \xe2\x80\x9cHe\xe2\x80\x99s\r\na coming tonight.\xe2\x80\x9d Who being instructed to deliver those words and\r\ndisappear, fulfilled his mission like a tarry spirit, charged with a\r\nmysterious warning.\r\n\r\nThe Captain, well pleased to receive it, made preparation of pipes and\r\nrum and water, and awaited his visitor in the back parlour. At the hour\r\nof eight, a deep lowing, as of a nautical Bull, outside the shop-door,\r\nsucceeded by the knocking of a stick on the panel, announced to the\r\nlistening ear of Captain Cuttle, that Bunsby was alongside; whom he\r\ninstantly admitted, shaggy and loose, and with his stolid mahogany\r\nvisage, as usual, appearing to have no consciousness of anything before\r\nit, but to be attentively observing something that was taking place in\r\nquite another part of the world.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBunsby,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Captain, grasping him by the hand, \xe2\x80\x9cwhat cheer, my\r\nlad, what cheer?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cShipmet,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the voice within Bunsby, unaccompanied by any sign\r\non the part of the Commander himself, \xe2\x80\x9chearty, hearty.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBunsby!\xe2\x80\x9d said the Captain, rendering irrepressible homage to his\r\ngenius, \xe2\x80\x9chere you are! a man as can give an opinion as is brighter than\r\ndi\xe2\x80\x99monds\xe2\x80\x94and give me the lad with the tarry trousers as shines to me\r\nlike di\xe2\x80\x99monds bright, for which you\xe2\x80\x99ll overhaul the Stanfell\xe2\x80\x99s Budget,\r\nand when found make a note. Here you are, a man as gave an opinion in\r\nthis here very place, that has come true, every letter on it,\xe2\x80\x9d which\r\nthe Captain sincerely believed.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAy, ay?\xe2\x80\x9d growled Bunsby.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cEvery letter,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Captain.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFor why?\xe2\x80\x9d growled Bunsby, looking at his friend for the first time.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhich way? If so, why not? Therefore.\xe2\x80\x9d With these oracular words\xe2\x80\x94they\r\nseemed almost to make the Captain giddy; they launched him upon such a\r\nsea of speculation and conjecture\xe2\x80\x94the sage submitted to be helped off\r\nwith his pilot-coat, and accompanied his friend into the back parlour,\r\nwhere his hand presently alighted on the rum-bottle, from which he\r\nbrewed a stiff glass of grog; and presently afterwards on a pipe, which\r\nhe filled, lighted, and began to smoke.\r\n\r\nCaptain Cuttle, imitating his visitor in the matter of these\r\nparticulars, though the rapt and imperturbable manner of the great\r\nCommander was far above his powers, sat in the opposite corner of the\r\nfireside, observing him respectfully, and as if he waited for some\r\nencouragement or expression of curiosity on Bunsby\xe2\x80\x99s part which should\r\nlead him to his own affairs. But as the mahogany philosopher gave no\r\nevidence of being sentient of anything but warmth and tobacco, except\r\nonce, when taking his pipe from his lips to make room for his glass, he\r\nincidentally remarked with exceeding gruffness, that his name was Jack\r\nBunsby\xe2\x80\x94a declaration that presented but small opening for\r\nconversation\xe2\x80\x94the Captain bespeaking his attention in a short\r\ncomplimentary exordium, narrated the whole history of Uncle Sol\xe2\x80\x99s\r\ndeparture, with the change it had produced in his own life and\r\nfortunes; and concluded by placing the packet on the table.\r\n\r\nAfter a long pause, Mr Bunsby nodded his head.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOpen?\xe2\x80\x9d said the Captain.\r\n\r\nBunsby nodded again.\r\n\r\nThe Captain accordingly broke the seal, and disclosed to view two\r\nfolded papers, of which he severally read the endorsements, thus: \xe2\x80\x9cLast\r\nWill and Testament of Solomon Gills.\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9cLetter for Ned Cuttle.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nBunsby, with his eye on the coast of Greenland, seemed to listen for\r\nthe contents. The Captain therefore hemmed to clear his throat, and\r\nread the letter aloud.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x98My dear Ned Cuttle. When I left home for the West Indies\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHere the Captain stopped, and looked hard at Bunsby, who looked fixedly\r\nat the coast of Greenland.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x98in forlorn search of intelligence of my dear boy, I knew that if you\r\nwere acquainted with my design, you would thwart it, or accompany me;\r\nand therefore I kept it secret. You will easily forgive an old friend\xe2\x80\x99s folly then,\r\nand will feel for the restlessness and uncertainty in which he wandered\r\naway on such a wild voyage. So no more of that. I have little hope that\r\nmy poor boy will ever read these words, or gladden your eyes with the\r\nsight of his frank face any more.\xe2\x80\x99 No, no; no more,\xe2\x80\x9d said Captain\r\nCuttle, sorrowfully meditating; \xe2\x80\x9cno more. There he lays, all his days\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMr Bunsby, who had a musical ear, suddenly bellowed, \xe2\x80\x9cIn the Bays of\r\nBiscay, O!\xe2\x80\x9d which so affected the good Captain, as an appropriate\r\ntribute to departed worth, that he shook him by the hand in\r\nacknowledgment, and was fain to wipe his eyes.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, well!\xe2\x80\x9d said the Captain with a sigh, as the Lament of Bunsby\r\nceased to ring and vibrate in the skylight. \xe2\x80\x9cAffliction sore, long time\r\nhe bore, and let us overhaul the wollume, and there find it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPhysicians,\xe2\x80\x9d observed Bunsby, \xe2\x80\x9cwas in vain.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAy, ay, to be sure,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Captain, \xe2\x80\x9cwhat\xe2\x80\x99s the good o\xe2\x80\x99 them in two\r\nor three hundred fathoms o\xe2\x80\x99 water!\xe2\x80\x9d Then, returning to the letter, he\r\nread on:\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9c"But if he should be by, when it is opened;\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9d the Captain\r\ninvoluntarily looked round, and shook his head; \xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x98or should know of it\r\nat any other time;\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9d the Captain shook his head again; \xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x98my blessing on\r\nhim! Because the bearings\r\nof this obserwation lays in the application on it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBunsby!\xe2\x80\x9d said Captain Cuttle, who would seem to have estimated the\r\nvalue of his distinguished friend\xe2\x80\x99s opinions in proportion to the\r\nimmensity of the difficulty he experienced in making anything out of\r\nthem; \xe2\x80\x9cBunsby,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Captain, quite confounded by admiration, \xe2\x80\x9cyou\r\ncarry a weight of mind easy, as would swamp one of my tonnage soon.
