Go-ood-bye, sweet Miss Floy!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhere will you go, Susan?\xe2\x80\x9d asked her weeping mistress.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ve got a brother down in the country Miss\xe2\x80\x94a farmer in Essex,\xe2\x80\x9d said\r\nthe heart-broken Nipper, \xe2\x80\x9cthat keeps ever so many co-o-ows and pigs and\r\nI shall go down there by the coach and sto-op with him, and don\xe2\x80\x99t mind\r\nme, for I\xe2\x80\x99ve got money in the Savings Banks my dear, and needn\xe2\x80\x99t take\r\nanother service just yet, which I couldn\xe2\x80\x99t, couldn\xe2\x80\x99t, couldn\xe2\x80\x99t do, my\r\nheart\xe2\x80\x99s own mistress!\xe2\x80\x9d Susan finished with a burst of sorrow, which was\r\nopportunely broken by the voice of Mrs Pipchin talking downstairs; on\r\nhearing which, she dried her red and swollen eyes, and made a\r\nmelancholy feint of calling jauntily to Mr Towlinson to fetch a cab and\r\ncarry down her boxes.\r\n\r\nFlorence, pale and hurried and distressed, but withheld from useless\r\ninterference even here, by her dread of causing any new division\r\nbetween her father and his wife (whose stern, indignant face had been a\r\nwarning to her a few moments since), and by her apprehension of being\r\nin some way unconsciously connected already with the dismissal of her\r\nold servant and friend, followed, weeping, downstairs to Edith\xe2\x80\x99s\r\ndressing-room, whither Susan betook herself to make her parting\r\ncurtsey.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNow, here\xe2\x80\x99s the cab, and here\xe2\x80\x99s the boxes, get along with you, do!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nsaid Mrs Pipchin, presenting herself at the same moment. \xe2\x80\x9cI beg your\r\npardon, Ma\xe2\x80\x99am, but Mr Dombey\xe2\x80\x99s orders are imperative.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nEdith, sitting under the hands of her maid\xe2\x80\x94she was going out to\r\ndinner\xe2\x80\x94preserved her haughty face, and took not the least notice.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThere\xe2\x80\x99s your money,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mrs Pipchin, who, in pursuance of her\r\nsystem, and in recollection of the Mines, was accustomed to rout the\r\nservants about, as she had routed her young Brighton boarders; to the\r\neverlasting acidulation of Master Bitherstone, \xe2\x80\x9cand the sooner this\r\nhouse sees your back the better.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nSusan had no spirits even for the look that belonged to Ma Pipchin by\r\nright; so she dropped her curtsey to Mrs Dombey (who inclined her head\r\nwithout one word, and whose eye avoided everyone but Florence), and\r\ngave one last parting hug to her young mistress, and received her\r\nparting embrace in return. Poor Susan\xe2\x80\x99s face at this crisis, in the\r\nintensity of her feelings and the determined suffocation of her sobs,\r\nlest one should become audible and be a triumph to Mrs Pipchin,\r\npresented a series of the most extraordinary physiognomical phenomena\r\never witnessed.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI beg your pardon, Miss, I\xe2\x80\x99m sure,\xe2\x80\x9d said Towlinson, outside the door\r\nwith the boxes, addressing Florence, \xe2\x80\x9cbut Mr Toots is in the\r\ndrawing-room, and sends his compliments, and begs to know how Diogenes\r\nand Master is.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nQuick as thought, Florence glided out and hastened downstairs, where Mr\r\nToots, in the most splendid vestments, was breathing very hard with\r\ndoubt and agitation on the subject of her coming.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, how de do, Miss Dombey,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mr Toots, \xe2\x80\x9cGod bless my soul!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThis last ejaculation was occasioned by Mr Toots\xe2\x80\x99s deep concern at the\r\ndistress he saw in Florence\xe2\x80\x99s face; which caused him to stop short in a\r\nfit of chuckles, and become an image of despair.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDear Mr Toots,\xe2\x80\x9d said Florence, \xe2\x80\x9cyou are so friendly to me, and so\r\nhonest, that I am sure I may ask a favour of you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMiss Dombey,\xe2\x80\x9d returned Mr Toots, \xe2\x80\x9cif you\xe2\x80\x99ll only name one,\r\nyou\xe2\x80\x99ll\xe2\x80\x94you\xe2\x80\x99ll give me an appetite. To which,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mr Toots, with some\r\nsentiment, \xe2\x80\x9cI have long been a stranger.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSusan, who is an old friend of mine, the oldest friend I have,\xe2\x80\x9d said\r\nFlorence, \xe2\x80\x9cis about to leave here suddenly, and quite alone, poor girl.\r\nShe is going home, a little way into the country. Might I ask you to\r\ntake care of her until she is in the coach?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMiss Dombey,\xe2\x80\x9d returned Mr Toots, \xe2\x80\x9cyou really do me an honour and a\r\nkindness. This proof of your confidence, after the manner in which I\r\nwas Beast enough to conduct myself at Brighton\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes,\xe2\x80\x9d said Florence, hurriedly\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cno\xe2\x80\x94don\xe2\x80\x99t think of that. Then would you\r\nhave the kindness to\xe2\x80\x94to go? and to be ready to meet her when she comes\r\nout? Thank you a thousand times! You ease my mind so much. She doesn\xe2\x80\x99t\r\nseem so desolate. You cannot think how grateful I feel to you, or what\r\na good friend I am sure you are!\xe2\x80\x9d and Florence in her earnestness\r\nthanked him again and again; and Mr Toots, in his earnestness, hurried\r\naway\xe2\x80\x94but backwards, that he might lose no glimpse of her.\r\n\r\nFlorence had not the courage to go out, when she saw poor Susan in the\r\nhall, with Mrs Pipchin driving her forth, and Diogenes jumping about\r\nher, and terrifying Mrs Pipchin to the last degree by making snaps at\r\nher bombazeen skirts, and howling with anguish at the sound of her\r\nvoice\xe2\x80\x94for the good duenna was the dearest and most cherished aversion\r\nof his breast. But she saw Susan shake hands with the servants all\r\nround, and turn once to look at her old home; and she saw Diogenes\r\nbound out after the cab, and want to follow it, and testify an\r\nimpossibility of conviction that he had no longer any property in the\r\nfare; and the door was shut, and the hurry over, and her tears flowed\r\nfast for the loss of an old friend, whom no one could replace. No one.\r\nNo one.\r\n\r\nMr Toots, like the leal and trusty soul he was, stopped the cabriolet\r\nin a twinkling, and told Susan Nipper of his commission, at which she\r\ncried more than before.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cUpon my soul and body!\xe2\x80\x9d said Mr Toots, taking his seat beside her. \xe2\x80\x9cI\r\nfeel for you. Upon my word and honour I think you can hardly know your\r\nown feelings better than I imagine them. I can conceive nothing more\r\ndreadful than to have to leave Miss Dombey.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nSusan abandoned herself to her grief now, and it really was touching to\r\nsee her.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI say,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mr Toots, \xe2\x80\x9cnow, don\xe2\x80\x99t! at least I mean now do, you know!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo what, Mr Toots!\xe2\x80\x9d cried Susan.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy, come home to my place, and have some dinner before you start,\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nsaid Mr Toots. \xe2\x80\x9cMy cook\xe2\x80\x99s a most respectable woman\xe2\x80\x94one of the most\r\nmotherly people I ever saw\xe2\x80\x94and she\xe2\x80\x99ll be delighted to make you\r\ncomfortable. Her son,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mr Toots, as an additional recommendation,\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cwas educated in the Bluecoat School, and blown up in a powder-mill.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nSusan accepting this kind offer, Mr Toots conducted her to his\r\ndwelling, where they were received by the Matron in question who fully\r\njustified his character of her, and by the Chicken who at first\r\nsupposed, on seeing a lady in the vehicle, that Mr Dombey had been\r\ndoubled up, agreeably to his old recommendation, and Miss Dombey\r\nabducted. This gentleman awakened in Miss Nipper some considerable\r\nastonishment; for, having been defeated by the Larkey Boy, his visage\r\nwas in a state of such great dilapidation, as to be hardly presentable\r\nin society with comfort to the beholders. The Chicken himself\r\nattributed this punishment to his having had the misfortune to get into\r\nChancery early in the proceedings, when he was severely fibbed by the\r\nLarkey one, and heavily grassed. But it appeared from the published\r\nrecords of that great contest that the Larkey Boy had had it all his\r\nown way from the beginning, and that the Chicken had been tapped, and\r\nbunged, and had received pepper, and had been made groggy, and had come\r\nup piping, and had endured a complication of similar strange\r\ninconveniences, until he had been gone into and finished.\r\n\r\nAfter a good repast, and much hospitality, Susan set out for the\r\ncoach-office in another cabriolet, with Mr Toots inside, as before, and\r\nthe Chicken on the box, who, whatever distinction he conferred on the\r\nlittle party by the moral weight and heroism of his character, was\r\nscarcely ornamental to it, physically speaking, on account of his\r\nplasters; which were numerous. But the Chicken had registered a vow, in\r\nsecret, that he would never leave Mr Toots (who was secretly pining to\r\nget rid of him), for any less consideration than the good-will and\r\nfixtures of a public-house; and being ambitious to go into that line,\r\nand drink himself to death as soon as possible, he felt it his cue to\r\nmake his company unacceptable.\r\n\r\nThe night-coach by which Susan was to go, was on the point of\r\ndeparture. Mr Toots having put her inside, lingered by the window,\r\nirresolutely, until the driver was about to mount; when, standing on\r\nthe step, and putting in a face that by the light of the lamp was\r\nanxious and confused, he said abruptly:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI say, Susan! Miss Dombey, you know\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, Sir.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo you think she could\xe2\x80\x94you know\xe2\x80\x94eh?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI beg your pardon, Mr Toots,\xe2\x80\x9d said Susan, \xe2\x80\x9cbut I don\xe2\x80\x99t hear you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo you think she could be brought, you know\xe2\x80\x94not exactly at once, but\r\nin time\xe2\x80\x94in a long time\xe2\x80\x94to\xe2\x80\x94to love me, you know? There!\xe2\x80\x9d said poor Mr\r\nToots.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh dear no!\xe2\x80\x9d returned Susan, shaking her head. \xe2\x80\x9cI should say, never.\r\nNever!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThank\xe2\x80\x99ee!\xe2\x80\x9d said Mr Toots. \xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s of no consequence. Good-night. It\xe2\x80\x99s of\r\nno consequence, thank\xe2\x80\x99ee!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER XLV.\r\nThe Trusty Agent\r\n\r\n\r\nEdith went out alone that day, and returned home early. It was but a\r\nfew minutes after ten o\xe2\x80\x99clock, when her carriage rolled along the\r\nstreet in which she lived.\r\n\r\nThere was the same enforced composure on her face, that there had been\r\nwhen she was dressing; and the wreath upon her head encircled the same\r\ncold and steady brow. But it would have been better to have seen its\r\nleaves and flowers reft into fragments by her passionate hand, or\r\nrendered shapeless by the fitful searches of a throbbing and bewildered\r\nbrain for any resting-place, than adorning such tranquillity. So\r\nobdurate, so unapproachable, so unrelenting, one would have thought\r\nthat nothing could soften such a woman\xe2\x80\x99s nature, and that everything in\r\nlife had hardened it.\r\n\r\nArrived at her own door, she was alighting, when some one coming\r\nquietly from the hall, and standing bareheaded, offered her his arm.\r\nThe servant being thrust aside, she had no choice but to touch it; and\r\nshe then knew whose arm it was.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow is your patient, Sir?\xe2\x80\x9d she asked, with a curled lip.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe is better,\xe2\x80\x9d returned Carker. \xe2\x80\x9cHe is doing very well. I have left\r\nhim for the night.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nShe bent her head, and was passing up the staircase, when he followed\r\nand said, speaking at the bottom:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMadam! May I beg the favour of a minute\xe2\x80\x99s audience?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nShe stopped and turned her eyes back \xe2\x80\x9cIt is an unseasonable time, Sir,\r\nand I am fatigued. Is your business urgent?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is very urgent, returned Carker. \xe2\x80\x9cAs I am so fortunate as to have\r\nmet you, let me press my petition.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nShe looked down for a moment at his glistening mouth; and he looked up\r\nat her, standing above him in her stately dress, and thought, again,\r\nhow beautiful she was.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhere is Miss Dombey?\xe2\x80\x9d she asked the servant, aloud.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIn the morning room, Ma\xe2\x80\x99am.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cShow the way there!\xe2\x80\x9d Turning her eyes again on the attentive gentleman\r\nat the bottom of the stairs, and informing him with a slight motion of\r\nher head, that he was at liberty to follow, she passed on.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI beg your pardon! Madam! Mrs Dombey!\xe2\x80\x9d cried the soft and nimble\r\nCarker, at her side in a moment. \xe2\x80\x9cMay I be permitted to entreat that\r\nMiss Dombey is not present?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nShe confronted him, with a quick look, but with the same\r\nself-possession and steadiness.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI would spare Miss Dombey,\xe2\x80\x9d said Carker, in a low voice, \xe2\x80\x9cthe\r\nknowledge of what I have to say. At least, Madam, I would leave it to\r\nyou to decide whether she shall know of it or not. I owe that to you.\r\nIt is my bounden duty to you. After our former interview, it would be\r\nmonstrous in me if I did otherwise.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nShe slowly withdrew her eyes from his face, and turning to the servant,\r\nsaid, \xe2\x80\x9cSome other room.\xe2\x80\x9d He led the way to a drawing-room, which he\r\nspeedily lighted up and then left them. While he remained, not a word\r\nwas spoken. Edith enthroned herself upon a couch by the fire; and Mr\r\nCarker, with his hat in his hand and his eyes bent upon the carpet,\r\nstood before her, at some little distance.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBefore I hear you, Sir,\xe2\x80\x9d said Edith, when the door was closed, \xe2\x80\x9cI wish\r\nyou to hear me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTo be addressed by Mrs Dombey,\xe2\x80\x9d he returned, \xe2\x80\x9ceven in accents of\r\nunmerited reproach, is an honour I so greatly esteem, that although I\r\nwere not her servant in all things, I should defer to such a wish, most\r\nreadily.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf you are charged by the man whom you have just now left, Sir;\xe2\x80\x9d Mr\r\nCarker raised his eyes, as if he were going to counterfeit surprise,\r\nbut she met them, and stopped him, if such were his intention; \xe2\x80\x9cwith\r\nany message to me, do not attempt to deliver it, for I will not receive\r\nit. I need scarcely ask you if you are come on such an errand. I have\r\nexpected you some time.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is my misfortune,\xe2\x80\x9d he replied, \xe2\x80\x9cto be here, wholly against my will,\r\nfor such a purpose. Allow me to say that I am here for two purposes.\r\nThat is one.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat one, Sir,\xe2\x80\x9d she returned, \xe2\x80\x9cis ended. Or, if you return to it\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCan Mrs Dombey believe,\xe2\x80\x9d said Carker, coming nearer, \xe2\x80\x9cthat I would\r\nreturn to it in the face of her prohibition? Is it possible that Mrs\r\nDombey, having no regard to my unfortunate position, is so determined\r\nto consider me inseparable from my instructor as to do me great and\r\nwilful injustice?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSir,\xe2\x80\x9d returned Edith, bending her dark gaze full upon him, and\r\nspeaking with a rising passion that inflated her proud nostril and her\r\nswelling neck, and stirred the delicate white down upon a robe she\r\nwore, thrown loosely over shoulders that could bear its snowy\r\nneighbourhood, \xe2\x80\x9cWhy do you present yourself to me, as you have done,\r\nand speak to me of love and duty to my husband, and pretend to think\r\nthat I am happily married, and that I honour him? How dare you venture\r\nso to affront me, when you know\xe2\x80\x94_I_ do not know better, Sir: I have\r\nseen it in your every glance, and heard it in your every word\xe2\x80\x94that in\r\nplace of affection between us there is aversion and contempt, and that\r\nI despise him hardly less than I despise myself for being his!\r\nInjustice! If I had done justice to the torment you have made me feel,\r\nand to my sense of the insult you have put upon me, I should have slain\r\nyou!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nShe had asked him why he did this. Had she not been blinded by her\r\npride and wrath, and self-humiliation,\xe2\x80\x94which she was, fiercely as she\r\nbent her gaze upon him,\xe2\x80\x94she would have seen the answer in his face. To\r\nbring her to this declaration.\r\n\r\nShe saw it not, and cared not whether it was there or no. She saw only\r\nthe indignities and struggles she had undergone and had to undergo, and\r\nwas writhing under them. As she sat looking fixedly at them, rather\r\nthan at him, she plucked the feathers from a pinion of some rare and\r\nbeautiful bird, which hung from her wrist by a golden thread, to serve\r\nher as a fan, and rained them on the ground.\r\n\r\nHe did not shrink beneath her gaze, but stood, until such outward signs\r\nof her anger as had escaped her control subsided, with the air of a man\r\nwho had his sufficient reply in reserve and would presently deliver it.\r\nAnd he then spoke, looking straight into her kindling eyes.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMadam,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, \xe2\x80\x9cI know, and knew before today, that I have found no\r\nfavour with you; and I knew why. Yes. I knew why. You have spoken so\r\nopenly to me; I am so relieved by the possession of your confidence\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cConfidence!\xe2\x80\x9d she repeated, with disdain.\r\n\r\nHe passed it over.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x94that I will make no pretence of concealment. I did see from the\r\nfirst, that there was no affection on your part for Mr Dombey\xe2\x80\x94how could\r\nit possibly exist between such different subjects? And I have seen,\r\nsince, that stronger feelings than indifference have been engendered in\r\nyour breast\xe2\x80\x94how could that possibly be otherwise, either, circumstanced\r\nas you have been? But was it for me to presume to avow this knowledge\r\nto you in so many words?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWas it for you, Sir,\xe2\x80\x9d she replied, \xe2\x80\x9cto feign that other belief, and\r\naudaciously to thrust it on me day by day?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMadam, it was,\xe2\x80\x9d he eagerly retorted. \xe2\x80\x9cIf I had done less, if I had\r\ndone anything but that, I should not be speaking to you thus; and I\r\nforesaw\xe2\x80\x94who could better foresee, for who has had greater experience of\r\nMr Dombey than myself?\xe2\x80\x94that unless your character should prove to be as\r\nyielding and obedient as that of his first submissive lady, which I did\r\nnot believe\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nA haughty smile gave him reason to observe that he might repeat this.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI say, which I did not believe,\xe2\x80\x94the time was likely to come, when such\r\nan understanding as we have now arrived at, would be serviceable.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cServiceable to whom, Sir?\xe2\x80\x9d she demanded scornfully.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTo you. I will not add to myself, as warning me to refrain even from\r\nthat limited commendation of Mr Dombey, in which I can honestly\r\nindulge, in order that I may not have the misfortune of saying anything\r\ndistasteful to one whose aversion and contempt,\xe2\x80\x9d with great expression,\r\n\xe2\x80\x9care so keen.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIs it honest in you, Sir,\xe2\x80\x9d said Edith, \xe2\x80\x9cto confess to your \xe2\x80\x98limited\r\ncommendation,\xe2\x80\x99 and to speak in that tone of disparagement, even of him:\r\nbeing his chief counsellor and flatterer!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCounsellor,\xe2\x80\x94yes,\xe2\x80\x9d said Carker. \xe2\x80\x9cFlatterer,\xe2\x80\x94no. A little reservation I\r\nfear I must confess to. But our interest and convenience commonly\r\noblige many of us to make professions that we cannot feel. We have\r\npartnerships of interest and convenience, friendships of interest and\r\nconvenience, dealings of interest and convenience, marriages of\r\ninterest and convenience, every day.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nShe bit her blood-red lip; but without wavering in the dark, stern\r\nwatch she kept upon him.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMadam,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mr Carker, sitting down in a chair that was near her,\r\nwith an air of the most profound and most considerate respect, \xe2\x80\x9cwhy\r\nshould I hesitate now, being altogether devoted to your service, to\r\nspeak plainly? It was natural that a lady, endowed as you are, should\r\nthink it feasible to change her husband\xe2\x80\x99s character in some respects,\r\nand mould him to a better form.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt was not natural to me, Sir,\xe2\x80\x9d she rejoined. \xe2\x80\x9cI had never any\r\nexpectation or intention of that kind.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe proud undaunted face showed him it was resolute to wear no mask he\r\noffered, but was set upon a reckless disclosure of itself, indifferent\r\nto any aspect in which it might present itself to such as he.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAt least it was natural,\xe2\x80\x9d he resumed, \xe2\x80\x9cthat you should deem it quite\r\npossible to live with Mr Dombey as his wife, at once without submitting\r\nto him, and without coming into such violent collision with him. But,\r\nMadam, you did not know Mr Dombey (as you have since ascertained), when\r\nyou thought that. You did not know how exacting and how proud he is, or\r\nhow he is, if I may say so, the slave of his own greatness, and goes\r\nyoked to his own triumphal car like a beast of burden, with no idea on\r\nearth but that it is behind him and is to be drawn on, over everything\r\nand through everything.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHis teeth gleamed through his malicious relish of this conceit, as he\r\nwent on talking:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMr Dombey is really capable of no more true consideration for you,\r\nMadam, than for me. The comparison is an extreme one; I intend it to be\r\nso; but quite just. Mr Dombey, in the plenitude of his power, asked\r\nme\xe2\x80\x94I had it from his own lips yesterday morning\xe2\x80\x94to be his go-between to\r\nyou, because he knows I am not agreeable to you, and because he intends\r\nthat I shall be a punishment for your contumacy; and besides that,\r\nbecause he really does consider, that I, his paid servant, am an\r\nambassador whom it is derogatory to the dignity\xe2\x80\x94not of the lady to whom\r\nI have the happiness of speaking; she has no existence in his mind\xe2\x80\x94but\r\nof his wife, a part of himself, to receive. You may imagine how\r\nregardless of me, how obtuse to the possibility of my having any\r\nindividual sentiment or opinion he is, when he tells me, openly, that I\r\nam so employed. You know how perfectly indifferent to your feelings he\r\nis, when he threatens you with such a messenger. As you, of course,\r\nhave not forgotten that he did.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nShe watched him still attentively. But he watched her too; and he saw\r\nthat this indication of a knowledge on his part, of something that had\r\npassed between herself and her husband, rankled and smarted in her\r\nhaughty breast, like a poisoned arrow.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI do not recall all this to widen the breach between yourself and Mr\r\nDombey, Madam\xe2\x80\x94Heaven forbid! what would it profit me?\xe2\x80\x94but as an example\r\nof the hopelessness of impressing Mr Dombey with a sense that anybody\r\nis to be considered when he is in question. We who are about him, have,\r\nin our various positions, done our part, I daresay, to confirm him in\r\nhis way of thinking; but if we had not done so, others would\xe2\x80\x94or they\r\nwould not have been about him; and it has always been, from the\r\nbeginning, the very staple of his life. Mr Dombey has had to deal, in\r\nshort, with none but submissive and dependent persons, who have bowed\r\nthe knee, and bent the neck, before him. He has never known what it is\r\nto have angry pride and strong resentment opposed to him.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut he will know it now!\xe2\x80\x9d she seemed to say; though her lips did not\r\npart, nor her eyes falter. He saw the soft down tremble once again, and\r\nhe saw her lay the plumage of the beautiful bird against her bosom for\r\na moment; and he unfolded one more ring of the coil into which he had\r\ngathered himself.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMr Dombey, though a most honourable gentleman,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, \xe2\x80\x9cis so prone\r\nto pervert even facts to his own view, when he is at all opposed, in\r\nconsequence of the warp in his mind, that he\xe2\x80\x94can I give a better\r\ninstance than this!\xe2\x80\x94he sincerely believes (you will excuse the folly of\r\nwhat I am about to say; it not being mine) that his severe expression\r\nof opinion to his present wife, on a certain special occasion she may\r\nremember, before the lamented death of Mrs Skewton, produced a\r\nwithering effect, and for the moment quite subdued her!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nEdith laughed. How harshly and unmusically need not be described. It is\r\nenough that he was glad to hear her.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMadam,\xe2\x80\x9d he resumed, \xe2\x80\x9cI have done with this. Your own opinions are so\r\nstrong, and, I am persuaded, so unalterable,\xe2\x80\x9d he repeated those words\r\nslowly and with great emphasis, \xe2\x80\x9cthat I am almost afraid to incur your\r\ndispleasure anew, when I say that in spite of these defects and my full\r\nknowledge of them, I have become habituated to Mr Dombey, and esteem\r\nhim. But when I say so, it is not, believe me, for the mere sake of\r\nvaunting a feeling that is so utterly at variance with your own, and\r\nfor which you can have no sympathy\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94oh how distinct and plain and\r\nemphasized this was!\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cbut to give you an assurance of the zeal with\r\nwhich, in this unhappy matter, I am yours, and the indignation with\r\nwhich I regard the part I am to fill!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nShe sat as if she were afraid to take her eyes from his face.\r\n\r\nAnd now to unwind the last ring of the coil!\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is growing late,\xe2\x80\x9d said Carker, after a pause, \xe2\x80\x9cand you are, as you\r\nsaid, fatigued. But the second object of this interview, I must not\r\nforget. I must recommend you, I must entreat you in the most earnest\r\nmanner, for sufficient reasons that I have, to be cautious in your\r\ndemonstrations of regard for Miss Dombey.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCautious! What do you mean?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTo be careful how you exhibit too much affection for that young lady.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cToo much affection, Sir!\xe2\x80\x9d said Edith, knitting her broad brow and\r\nrising. \xe2\x80\x9cWho judges my affection, or measures it out? You?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is not I who do so.\xe2\x80\x9d He was, or feigned to be, perplexed.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWho then?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCan you not guess who then?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI do not choose to guess,\xe2\x80\x9d she answered.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMadam,\xe2\x80\x9d he said after a little hesitation; meantime they had been, and\r\nstill were, regarding each other as before; \xe2\x80\x9cI am in a difficulty here.\r\nYou have told me you will receive no message, and you have forbidden me\r\nto return to that subject; but the two subjects are so closely\r\nentwined, I find, that unless you will accept this vague caution from\r\none who has now the honour to possess your confidence, though the way\r\nto it has been through your displeasure, I must violate the injunction\r\nyou have laid upon me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou know that you are free to do so, Sir,\xe2\x80\x9d said Edith. \xe2\x80\x9cDo it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nSo pale, so trembling, so impassioned! He had not miscalculated the\r\neffect then!\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHis instructions were,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, in a low voice, \xe2\x80\x9cthat I should inform\r\nyou that your demeanour towards Miss Dombey is not agreeable to him.\r\nThat it suggests comparisons to him which are not favourable to\r\nhimself. That he desires it may be wholly changed; and that if you are\r\nin earnest, he is confident it will be; for your continued show of\r\naffection will not benefit its object.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat is a threat,\xe2\x80\x9d she said.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat is a threat,\xe2\x80\x9d he answered, in his voiceless manner of assent:\r\nadding aloud, \xe2\x80\x9cbut not directed against you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nProud, erect, and dignified, as she stood confronting him; and looking\r\nthrough him as she did, with her full bright flashing eye; and smiling,\r\nas she was, with scorn and bitterness; she sunk as if the ground had\r\ndropped beneath her, and in an instant would have fallen on the floor,\r\nbut that he caught her in his arms. As instantaneously she threw him\r\noff, the moment that he touched her, and, drawing back, confronted him\r\nagain, immoveable, with her hand stretched out.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPlease to leave me. Say no more tonight.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI feel the urgency of this,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mr Carker, \xe2\x80\x9cbecause it is impossible\r\nto say what unforeseen consequences might arise, or how soon, from your\r\nbeing unacquainted with his state of mind. I understand Miss Dombey is\r\nconcerned, now, at the dismissal of her old servant, which is likely to\r\nhave been a minor consequence in itself. You don\xe2\x80\x99t blame me for\r\nrequesting that Miss Dombey might not be present. May I hope so?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI do not. Please to leave me, Sir.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI knew that your regard for the young lady, which is very sincere and\r\nstrong, I am well persuaded, would render it a great unhappiness to\r\nyou, ever to be a prey to the reflection that you had injured her\r\nposition and ruined her future hopes,\xe2\x80\x9d said Carker hurriedly, but\r\neagerly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo more tonight. Leave me, if you please.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI shall be here constantly in my attendance upon him, and in the\r\ntransaction of business matters. You will allow me to see you again,\r\nand to consult what should be done, and learn your wishes?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nShe motioned him towards the door.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI cannot even decide whether to tell him I have spoken to you yet; or\r\nto lead him to suppose that I have deferred doing so, for want of\r\nopportunity, or for any other reason. It will be necessary that you\r\nshould enable me to consult with you very soon.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAt any time but now,\xe2\x80\x9d she answered.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou will understand, when I wish to see you, that Miss Dombey is not\r\nto be present; and that I seek an interview as one who has the\r\nhappiness to possess your confidence, and who comes to render you every\r\nassistance in his power, and, perhaps, on many occasions, to ward off\r\nevil from her?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nLooking at him still with the same apparent dread of releasing him for\r\na moment from the influence of her steady gaze, whatever that might be,\r\nshe answered, \xe2\x80\x9cYes!\xe2\x80\x9d and once more bade him go.\r\n\r\nHe bowed, as if in compliance; but turning back, when he had nearly\r\nreached the door, said:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am forgiven, and have explained my fault. May I\xe2\x80\x94for Miss Dombey\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nsake, and for my own\xe2\x80\x94take your hand before I go?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nShe gave him the gloved hand she had maimed last night. He took it in\r\none of his, and kissed it, and withdrew. And when he had closed the\r\ndoor, he waved the hand with which he had taken hers, and thrust it in\r\nhis breast.\r\n\r\nEdith saw no one that night, but locked her door, and kept herself\r\nalone.\r\n\r\nShe did not weep; she showed no greater agitation, outwardly, than when\r\nshe was riding home. She laid as proud a head upon her pillow as she\r\nhad borne in her carriage; and her prayer ran thus:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMay this man be a liar! For if he has spoken truth, she is lost to me,\r\nand I have no hope left!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThis man, meanwhile, went home musing to bed, thinking, with a dainty\r\npleasure, how imperious her passion was, how she had sat before him in\r\nher beauty, with the dark eyes that had never turned away but once; how\r\nthe white down had fluttered; how the bird\xe2\x80\x99s feathers had been strewn\r\nupon the ground.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER XLVI.\r\nRecognizant and Reflective\r\n\r\n\r\nAmong sundry minor alterations in Mr Carker\xe2\x80\x99s life and habits that\r\nbegan to take place at this time, none was more remarkable than the\r\nextraordinary diligence with which he applied himself to business, and\r\nthe closeness with which he investigated every detail that the affairs\r\nof the House laid open to him. Always active and penetrating in such\r\nmatters, his lynx-eyed vigilance now increased twenty-fold. Not only\r\ndid his weary watch keep pace with every present point that every day\r\npresented to him in some new form, but in the midst of these engrossing\r\noccupations he found leisure\xe2\x80\x94that is, he made it\xe2\x80\x94to review the past\r\ntransactions of the Firm, and his share in them, during a long series\r\nof years. Frequently when the clerks were all gone, the offices dark\r\nand empty, and all similar places of business shut up, Mr Carker, with\r\nthe whole anatomy of the iron room laid bare before him, would explore\r\nthe mysteries of books and papers, with the patient progress of a man\r\nwho was dissecting the minutest nerves and fibres of his subject.\r\nPerch, the messenger, who usually remained on these occasions, to\r\nentertain himself with the perusal of the Price Current by the light of\r\none candle, or to doze over the fire in the outer office, at the\r\nimminent risk every moment of diving head foremost into the coal-box,\r\ncould not withhold the tribute of his admiration from this zealous\r\nconduct, although it much contracted his domestic enjoyments; and\r\nagain, and again, expatiated to Mrs Perch (now nursing twins) on the\r\nindustry and acuteness of their managing gentleman in the City.\r\n\r\nThe same increased and sharp attention that Mr Carker bestowed on the\r\nbusiness of the House, he applied to his own personal affairs. Though\r\nnot a partner in the concern\xe2\x80\x94a distinction hitherto reserved solely to\r\ninheritors of the great name of Dombey\xe2\x80\x94he was in the receipt of some\r\npercentage on its dealings; and, participating in all its facilities\r\nfor the employment of money to advantage, was considered, by the\r\nminnows among the tritons of the East, a rich man. It began to be said,\r\namong these shrewd observers, that Jem Carker, of Dombey\xe2\x80\x99s, was looking\r\nabout him to see what he was worth; and that he was calling in his\r\nmoney at a good time, like the long-headed fellow he was; and bets were\r\neven offered on the Stock Exchange that Jem was going to marry a rich\r\nwidow.\r\n\r\nYet these cares did not in the least interfere with Mr Carker\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nwatching of his chief, or with his cleanness, neatness, sleekness, or\r\nany cat-like quality he possessed. It was not so much that there was a\r\nchange in him, in reference to any of his habits, as that the whole man\r\nwas intensified. Everything that had been observable in him before, was\r\nobservable now, but with a greater amount of concentration. He did each\r\nsingle thing, as if he did nothing else\xe2\x80\x94a pretty certain indication in\r\na man of that range of ability and purpose, that he is doing something\r\nwhich sharpens and keeps alive his keenest powers.\r\n\r\nThe only decided alteration in him was, that as he rode to and fro\r\nalong the streets, he would fall into deep fits of musing, like that in\r\nwhich he had come away from Mr Dombey\xe2\x80\x99s house, on the morning of that\r\ngentleman\xe2\x80\x99s disaster. At such times, he would keep clear of the\r\nobstacles in his way, mechanically; and would appear to see and hear\r\nnothing until arrival at his destination, or some sudden chance or\r\neffort roused him.\r\n\r\nWalking his white-legged horse thus, to the counting-house of Dombey\r\nand Son one day, he was as unconscious of the observation of two pairs\r\nof women\xe2\x80\x99s eyes, as of the fascinated orbs of Rob the Grinder, who, in\r\nwaiting a street\xe2\x80\x99s length from the appointed place, as a demonstration\r\nof punctuality, vainly touched and retouched his hat to attract\r\nattention, and trotted along on foot, by his master\xe2\x80\x99s side, prepared to\r\nhold his stirrup when he should alight.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSee where he goes!\xe2\x80\x9d cried one of these two women, an old creature, who\r\nstretched out her shrivelled arm to point him out to her companion, a\r\nyoung woman, who stood close beside her, withdrawn like herself into a\r\ngateway.\r\n\r\nMrs Brown\xe2\x80\x99s daughter looked out, at this bidding on the part of Mrs\r\nBrown; and there were wrath and vengeance in her face.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI never thought to look at him again,\xe2\x80\x9d she said, in a low voice; \xe2\x80\x9cbut\r\nit\xe2\x80\x99s well I should, perhaps. I see. I see!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNot changed!\xe2\x80\x9d said the old woman, with a look of eager malice.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe changed!\xe2\x80\x9d returned the other. \xe2\x80\x9cWhat for? What has he suffered?\r\nThere is change enough for twenty in me. Isn\xe2\x80\x99t that enough?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSee where he goes!\xe2\x80\x9d muttered the old woman, watching her daughter with\r\nher red eyes; \xe2\x80\x9cso easy and so trim a-horseback, while we are in the\r\nmud.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd of it,\xe2\x80\x9d said her daughter impatiently. \xe2\x80\x9cWe are mud, underneath his\r\nhorse\xe2\x80\x99s feet. What should we be?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n[Illustration]\r\n\r\nIn the intentness with which she looked after him again, she made a\r\nhasty gesture with her hand when the old woman began to reply, as if\r\nher view could be obstructed by mere sound. Her mother watching her,\r\nand not him, remained silent; until her kindling glance subsided, and\r\nshe drew a long breath, as if in the relief of his being gone.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDeary!\xe2\x80\x9d said the old woman then. \xe2\x80\x9cAlice! Handsome gall Ally!\xe2\x80\x9d She\r\ngently shook her sleeve to arouse her attention. \xe2\x80\x9cWill you let him go\r\nlike that, when you can wring money from him? Why, it\xe2\x80\x99s a wickedness,\r\nmy daughter.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHaven\xe2\x80\x99t I told you, that I will not have money from him?\xe2\x80\x9d she\r\nreturned. \xe2\x80\x9cAnd don\xe2\x80\x99t you yet believe me? Did I take his sister\xe2\x80\x99s money?\r\nWould I touch a penny, if I knew it, that had gone through his white\r\nhands\xe2\x80\x94unless it was, indeed, that I could poison it, and send it back\r\nto him? Peace, mother, and come away.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd him so rich?\xe2\x80\x9d murmured the old woman. \xe2\x80\x9cAnd us so poor!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPoor in not being able to pay him any of the harm we owe him,\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nreturned her daughter. \xe2\x80\x9cLet him give me that sort of riches, and I\xe2\x80\x99ll\r\ntake them from him, and use them. Come away. Its no good looking at his\r\nhorse. Come away, mother!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nBut the old woman, for whom the spectacle of Rob the Grinder returning\r\ndown the street, leading the riderless horse, appeared to have some\r\nextraneous interest that it did not possess in itself, surveyed that\r\nyoung man with the utmost earnestness; and seeming to have whatever\r\ndoubts she entertained, resolved as he drew nearer, glanced at her\r\ndaughter with brightened eyes and with her finger on her lip, and\r\nemerging from the gateway at the moment of his passing, touched him on\r\nthe shoulder.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy, where\xe2\x80\x99s my sprightly Rob been, all this time!\xe2\x80\x9d she said, as he\r\nturned round.\r\n\r\nThe sprightly Rob, whose sprightliness was very much diminished by the\r\nsalutation, looked exceedingly dismayed, and said, with the water\r\nrising in his eyes:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh! why can\xe2\x80\x99t you leave a poor cove alone, Misses Brown, when he\xe2\x80\x99s\r\ngetting an honest livelihood and conducting himself respectable? What\r\ndo you come and deprive a cove of his character for, by talking to him\r\nin the streets, when he\xe2\x80\x99s taking his master\xe2\x80\x99s horse to a honest\r\nstable\xe2\x80\x94a horse you\xe2\x80\x99d go and sell for cats\xe2\x80\x99 and dogs\xe2\x80\x99 meat if you had\r\nyour way! Why, I thought,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Grinder, producing his concluding\r\nremark as if it were the climax of all his injuries, \xe2\x80\x9cthat you was dead\r\nlong ago!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThis is the way,\xe2\x80\x9d cried the old woman, appealing to her daughter,\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cthat he talks to me, who knew him weeks and months together, my deary,\r\nand have stood his friend many and many a time among the\r\npigeon-fancying tramps and bird-catchers.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLet the birds be, will you, Misses Brown?\xe2\x80\x9d retorted Rob, in a tone of\r\nthe acutest anguish. \xe2\x80\x9cI think a cove had better have to do with lions\r\nthan them little creeturs, for they\xe2\x80\x99re always flying back in your face\r\nwhen you least expect it. Well, how d\xe2\x80\x99ye do and what do you want?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nThese polite inquiries the Grinder uttered, as it were under protest,\r\nand with great exasperation and vindictiveness.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHark how he speaks to an old friend, my deary!\xe2\x80\x9d said Mrs Brown, again\r\nappealing to her daughter. \xe2\x80\x9cBut there\xe2\x80\x99s some of his old friends not so\r\npatient as me. If I was to tell some that he knows, and has spotted and\r\ncheated with, where to find him\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWill you hold your tongue, Misses Brown?\xe2\x80\x9d interrupted the miserable\r\nGrinder, glancing quickly round, as though he expected to see his\r\nmaster\xe2\x80\x99s teeth shining at his elbow. \xe2\x80\x9cWhat do you take a pleasure in\r\nruining a cove for? At your time of life too! when you ought to be\r\nthinking of a variety of things!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat a gallant horse!\xe2\x80\x9d said the old woman, patting the animal\xe2\x80\x99s neck.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLet him alone, will you, Misses Brown?\xe2\x80\x9d cried Rob, pushing away her\r\nhand. \xe2\x80\x9cYou\xe2\x80\x99re enough to drive a penitent cove mad!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy, what hurt do I do him, child?\xe2\x80\x9d returned the old woman.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHurt?\xe2\x80\x9d said Rob. \xe2\x80\x9cHe\xe2\x80\x99s got a master that would find it out if he was\r\ntouched with a straw.\xe2\x80\x9d And he blew upon the place where the old woman\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nhand had rested for a moment, and smoothed it gently with his finger,\r\nas if he seriously believed what he said.\r\n\r\nThe old woman looking back to mumble and mouth at her daughter, who\r\nfollowed, kept close to Rob\xe2\x80\x99s heels as he walked on with the bridle in\r\nhis hand; and pursued the conversation.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA good place, Rob, eh?\xe2\x80\x9d said she. \xe2\x80\x9cYou\xe2\x80\x99re in luck, my child.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh don\xe2\x80\x99t talk about luck, Misses Brown,\xe2\x80\x9d returned the wretched\r\nGrinder, facing round and stopping. \xe2\x80\x9cIf you\xe2\x80\x99d never come, or if you\xe2\x80\x99d\r\ngo away, then indeed a cove might be considered tolerable lucky. Can\xe2\x80\x99t\r\nyou go along, Misses Brown, and not foller me!\xe2\x80\x9d blubbered Rob, with\r\nsudden defiance. \xe2\x80\x9cIf the young woman\xe2\x80\x99s a friend of yours, why don\xe2\x80\x99t she\r\ntake you away, instead of letting you make yourself so disgraceful!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat!\xe2\x80\x9d croaked the old woman, putting her face close to his, with a\r\nmalevolent grin upon it that puckered up the loose skin down in her\r\nvery throat. \xe2\x80\x9cDo you deny your old chum! Have you lurked to my house\r\nfifty times, and slept sound in a corner when you had no other bed but\r\nthe paving-stones, and do you talk to me like this! Have I bought and\r\nsold with you, and helped you in my way of business, schoolboy, sneak,\r\nand what not, and do you tell me to go along? Could I raise a crowd of\r\nold company about you to-morrow morning, that would follow you to ruin\r\nlike copies of your own shadow, and do you turn on me with your bold\r\nlooks! I\xe2\x80\x99ll go. Come, Alice.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cStop, Misses Brown!\xe2\x80\x9d cried the distracted Grinder. \xe2\x80\x9cWhat are you doing\r\nof? Don\xe2\x80\x99t put yourself in a passion! Don\xe2\x80\x99t let her go, if you please. I\r\nhaven\xe2\x80\x99t meant any offence. I said \xe2\x80\x98how d\xe2\x80\x99ye do,\xe2\x80\x99 at first, didn\xe2\x80\x99t I?\r\nBut you wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t answer. How you do? Besides,\xe2\x80\x9d said Rob piteously,\r\n\xe2\x80\x9clook here! How can a cove stand talking in the street with his\r\nmaster\xe2\x80\x99s prad a-wanting to be took to be rubbed down, and his master up\r\nto every individgle thing that happens!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe old woman made a show of being partially appeased, but shook her\r\nhead, and mouthed and muttered still.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCome along to the stables, and have a glass of something that\xe2\x80\x99s good\r\nfor you, Misses Brown, can\xe2\x80\x99t you?\xe2\x80\x9d said Rob, \xe2\x80\x9cinstead of going on, like\r\nthat, which is no good to you, nor anybody else. The old woman, mouthing at her\r\ndaughter, followed close upon him. The daughter followed.\r\n\r\nTurning into a silent little square or court-yard that had a great\r\nchurch tower rising above it, and a packer\xe2\x80\x99s warehouse, and a\r\nbottle-maker\xe2\x80\x99s warehouse, for its places of business, Rob the Grinder\r\ndelivered the white-legged horse to the hostler of a quaint stable at\r\nthe corner; and inviting Mrs Brown and her daughter to seat themselves\r\nupon a stone bench at the gate of that establishment, soon reappeared\r\nfrom a neighbouring public-house with a pewter measure and a glass.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHere\xe2\x80\x99s master\xe2\x80\x94Mr Carker, child!\xe2\x80\x9d said the old woman, slowly, as her\r\nsentiment before drinking. \xe2\x80\x9cLord bless him!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy, I didn\xe2\x80\x99t tell you who he was,\xe2\x80\x9d observed Rob, with staring eyes.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWe know him by sight,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mrs Brown, whose working mouth and nodding\r\nhead stopped for the moment, in the fixedness of her attention. \xe2\x80\x9cWe saw\r\nhim pass this morning, afore he got off his horse; when you were ready\r\nto take it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAy, ay,\xe2\x80\x9d returned Rob, appearing to wish that his readiness had\r\ncarried him to any other place.\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cWhat\xe2\x80\x99s the matter with her? and added, in a low voice, \xe2\x80\x9cprecious sharp.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLives out of town, don\xe2\x80\x99t he, lovey?\xe2\x80\x9d said the old woman.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhen he\xe2\x80\x99s at home,\xe2\x80\x9d returned Rob; \xe2\x80\x9cand my master has to be up there, more than usual, either\r\nwith him, or Mrs Dombey, or some of \xe2\x80\x99em; and so we\xe2\x80\x99ve come to town.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAre they good friends, lovey?\xe2\x80\x9d asked the old woman.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWho?\xe2\x80\x9d retorted Rob.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe and she?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat, Mr and Mrs Dombey?\xe2\x80\x9d said Rob. \xe2\x80\x9cHow should I know!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNot them\xe2\x80\x94Master and Mrs Dombey, chick,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the old woman,\r\ncoaxingly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI don\xe2\x80\x99t know,\xe2\x80\x9d said Rob, looking round him again. \xe2\x80\x9cI suppose so. Least said, soonest mended.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy there\xe2\x80\x99s no harm in it!\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed the old woman, with a laugh, and\r\na clap of her hands. \xe2\x80\x9cSprightly Rob, has grown tame since he has been\r\nwell off! Do you mind so little what I said but now? Here. Take it!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe old woman uttered a moan as the money was restored, but without in\r\nany other way opposing its restoration, hobbled at her daughter\xe2\x80\x99s side\r\nout of the yard, and along the by-street upon which it opened. The\r\nastonished and dismayed Rob staring after them, saw that they stopped,\r\nand fell to earnest conversation very soon; and more than once observed\r\na darkly threatening action of the younger woman\xe2\x80\x99s hand (obviously\r\nhaving reference to someone of whom they spoke), and a crooning feeble\r\nimitation of it on the part of Mrs Brown, that made him earnestly hope\r\nhe might not be the subject of their discourse.\r\n\r\nWith the present consolation that they were gone, and with the\r\nprospective comfort that Mrs Brown could not live for ever, and was not\r\nlikely to live long to trouble him, the Grinder, not otherwise\r\nregretting his misdeeds than as they were attended with such\r\ndisagreeable incidental consequences, composed his ruffled features to\r\na more serene expression by thinking of the admirable manner in which\r\nhe had disposed of Captain Cuttle (a reflection that seldom failed to\r\nput him in a flow of spirits), and went to the Dombey Counting House to\r\nreceive his master\xe2\x80\x99s orders.\r\n\r\nThere his master, so subtle and vigilant of eye, that Rob quaked before\r\nhim, more than half expecting to be taxed with Mrs Brown, gave him the\r\nusual morning\xe2\x80\x99s box of papers for Mr Dombey, and a note for Mrs Dombey:\r\nmerely nodding his head as an enjoinder to be careful, and to use\r\ndispatch\xe2\x80\x94a mysterious admonition, fraught in the Grinder\xe2\x80\x99s imagination\r\nwith dismal warnings and threats; and more powerful with him than any\r\nwords.\r\n\r\nAlone again, in his own room, Mr Carker applied himself to work, and\r\nworked all day. He saw many visitors; overlooked a number of documents;\r\nwent in and out, to and from, sundry places of mercantile resort; and\r\nindulged in no more abstraction until the day\xe2\x80\x99s business was done. But,\r\nwhen the usual clearance of papers from his table was made at last, he\r\nfell into his thoughtful mood once more.\r\n\r\nHe was standing in his accustomed place and attitude, with his eyes\r\nintently fixed upon the ground, when his brother entered to bring back\r\nsome letters that had been taken out in the course of the day. He put\r\nthem quietly on the table, and was going immediately, when Mr Carker\r\nthe Manager, whose eyes had rested on him, on his entrance, as if they\r\nhad all this time had him for the subject of their contemplation,\r\ninstead of the office-floor, said:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, John Carker, and what brings you here?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHis brother pointed to the letters, and was again withdrawing.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI wonder,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Manager, \xe2\x80\x9cthat you can come and go, without\r\ninquiring how our master is\xe2\x80\x9d.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWe had word this morning in the Counting House, that Mr Dombey was\r\ndoing well,\xe2\x80\x9d replied his brother.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou are such a meek fellow,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Manager, with a smile,\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cbut you\r\nhave grown so, in the course of years\xe2\x80\x94that if any harm came to him,\r\nyou\xe2\x80\x99d be miserable, I dare swear now.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI should be truly sorry, James,\xe2\x80\x9d returned the other.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe would be sorry!\xe2\x80\x9d said the Manager, pointing at him, as if there\r\nwere some other person present to whom he was appealing. \xe2\x80\x9cHe would be\r\ntruly sorry! This brother of mine! This junior of the place, this\r\nslighted piece of lumber, pushed aside with his face to the wall, like\r\na rotten picture, and left so, for Heaven knows how many years he\xe2\x80\x99s all\r\ngratitude and respect, and devotion too, he would have me believe!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI would have you believe nothing, James,\xe2\x80\x9d returned the other. \xe2\x80\x9cBe as\r\njust to me as you would to any other man below you. You ask a question,\r\nand I answer it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd have you nothing, Spaniel,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Manager, with unusual\r\nirascibility, \xe2\x80\x9cto complain of in him? What the\r\ndevil! are you man or mouse?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt would be strange if any two persons could be together for so many\r\nyears, especially as superior and inferior, without each having\r\nsomething to complain of in the other\xe2\x80\x94as he thought, at all events,\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nreplied John Carker. \xe2\x80\x9cBut apart from my history here\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHis history here!\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed the Manager. \xe2\x80\x9cWhy, there it is. The very\r\nfact that makes him an extreme case, puts him out of the whole chapter!\r\nWell?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cApart from that, which, as you hint, gives me a reason to be thankful\r\nthat I alone (happily for all the rest) possess, surely there is no one\r\nin the House who would not say and feel at least as much.
